social_posts.post_text: In Tel Aviv we had quite a day of learning. And eating of course. After breakfast (you’ve seen the hotel breakfasts by now and the @danhotelsintlv is no exception!) Bob Goldman came to speak with us about Israel’s politics. It was enlightening and interesting and talking with Bob is always time very well spent. And then we were off for a class with @nofatamna at @danontlv - What can I say about Nof other than, when I eat certain dishes my mom will say “yes it’s delicious but just wait until you taste Nof’s” guess what? It’s true. She’s is brilliant and beautiful and funny and her food is outrageously delicious. Thank you Nof and your team. And then, we got to learn challah from @urischeft - also a total honour, he showed us braids and knots and artworks of challah and more braids and everyone got to make and take their own creations. Finally over dinner at Uri’s @lehamimbakery, @jladovsky joined us about his experience as a Canadian making aliya and joining the elite forces of the IDF. Another brilliant day. Thanks mom and everyone. #eatingisrael2022 #telaviv

There are a few different common substitutions when someone can’t eat sesame. Regular sesame oil can be substituted for any other neutral oil like sunflower or canola oil, but toasted sesame oil has a specific sesame flavour. Whatever you substitute won’t have that flavour, but a hazelnut or walnut oil will also be delicious. Or you could leave it out entirely and just add more of the other flavourful ingredients in the recipe. Instead of tahini - which is made from just sesame seeds - you could use a different nut butter like almond, peanut or cashew butter assuming there are no nut allergies to be concerned about. And instead of sesame seeds you could use other seeds like pumpkin seeds, sunflower seeds, poppy seeds or flax seeds! I hope you find this helpful and Comment below to tell us what you use as a substitution! #sesame #substitutions #motherdaughtercooking #dontworryjustcook

Okay one last post about my moms #eatingisrael2022 culinary tour! We’ve been back for five days or what feels like a very cold year (because two weeks in Israel missing fall will do that). Okay what you haven’t seen yet were two amazing days and so much incredible food in Tel Aviv. We visited @anumuseum (could have spent a whole day) before a beautiful lunch at @majdakitchen and a visit to @chefkamel to see how he makes his artisanal tahini and halva - both the best we’ve ever tasted (guess how much we all brought home!?) Dinner that night @north.abraxas was both outrageously delicious and a total show that I can’t do justice to in a post. But I’ve tried. We started our last day together at @asif.tlv for brunch and amazing learning about Israeli cuisine, had an awesome tour of Levinsky market from @bhukatours, visited @ikachocolate, and finally, dinner at Adeenas. We had the absolute pleasure of having dinner at home made by the lovely, warm and wonderful @adeenasussman. As a special treat @cafe_levinsky41 Benny was there to make gazoz cocktails, and Adeenas husband @jayshofet joined us too (and @leoraeatkiewicz and @galsc also big thanks!). There could be no better way to end the trip than with good friends and those who have become good friends. It’s not goodbye it’s just so long! Until year. #eatingisrael2022 #telaviv #asif #levinskymarket #anu #majda #northabraxis

Korean Inspired Glazed Roasted Salmon

I used my favourite Korean style glaze on this wonderful fish-roasting technique from @peaslovencarrots. So delicious. Use your favourite glaze. Use your favourite thick cut fish. I often serve this like a rice bowl with roasted or stir-fried vegetables.

Ingredients
1/3 cup soy sauce
3 tbsp brown sugar
1/2 tsp sriracha or gochujang
1 clove garlic, grated
1/2” piece peeled ginger, grated
grated peel of 1/2 orange
1/2 tsp toasted sesame oil
1 1/2 lb salmon fillet, skin on
1 green onion, thinly sliced on the diagonal or chives
steamed rice

Method
1.  In a 2-cup glass measure (or a small saucepan) stir together soy sauce, sugar, sriracha, garlic, ginger and orange peel. Cook in a microwave for 2 to 3 minutes (or in a saucepan on medium heat for 5 to 7 minutes) or until reduced by about half. Stir in sesame oil and cool slightly.
2.  Place the fillet of salmon on a baking sheet lined with parchment paper. Being careful not to cut through the skin, with a very sharp knife, cut slits in the salmon to create about 1 to 1 1/2 “ cubes.
3.  Preheat oven to 450F. Brush salmon all over with glaze and brush down into the slits. Roast 5 minutes. Brush again. Roast another 5 minutes. Brush again. Roast again just until cooked (about 5 to 7 minutes longer - you lose a little time when you open the oven to glaze).
4.  Sprinkle with green onions or chives. To serve, use a metal spatula to lift chunks of salmon off the skin and place on steamed rice.
Makes 4 servings

Espresso White Chocolate Blondies - These are easy and quick to make - slightly adapted from my recipe in Essentials of Home Cooking. You can omit espresso powder or use decaf; use gf flour (I used @cup4cup) instead of all-purpose and you can use milk chocolate instead of white. These freeze well - make them now for the holidays!
 
Ingredients

1/2 cup butter, diced if cold
1 1/4 cups brown sugar
2 eggs
1 tsp pure vanilla extract
2 tbsp instant espresso powder (or finely ground instant coffee)
1 cup all-purpose flour 
1/2 tsp baking powder
1/4 tsp kosher salt
3/4 cup toasted pecans, roughly chopped
3/4 cup chopped white chocolate or white chocolate chips
topping: (optional but looks and tastes great)
1/4 cup salted caramel or dulce de leche or about 2 oz melted white chocolate
25 to 30 toasted pecan halves
 
Method

1.Preheat oven to 350F. Butter or spray an 8" square baking dish and with parchment paper.

2.In a food processor or in a bowl with a hand mixer or wooden spoon, beat butter with brown sugar until smooth and light. Add eggs one at a time, beating after each addition. Add vanilla and espresso powder. Don't worry if batter looks separated - it will come together when flour is added.
	
3.In another bowl whisk flour with baking powder and salt and stir into butter mixture. Stir in chopped pecans and white chocolate. Transfer batter to prepared baking dish and bake 30 to 35 minutes or until just set in the centre. Do not overbake. Cool on a rack. 
	
4.For easy cutting, remove the 'cake' from the pan. chill and cut into squares. Drizzle with caramel or melted chocolate and top each piece with a pecan. Delicious at room temperature, cold or partially frozen!
Make 25 to 30 pieces

Mitchell’s Chocolate Cake with Ganache Icing  This deep, dark and delicious cake from our friend Mitchell Davis (@Kitchensense) and his sister Carrie is absolutely the best. It is really easy to make and you don’t even need a mixer. I like to make it in 2 8 inch round pans but it also makes great cupcakes (bake less time) or one 9 x 13 inch pan. This icing is rich and luscious and easy to make but you just have to let it cool enough so that it is spreadable.
Ingredients - cake:
1 3/4 cups all purpose flour
1 cup granulated sugar
1 cup brown sugar
3/4 cup cocoa powder
2 tsp baking soda
1 tsp baking powder
1/2 tsp kosher salt
2 eggs
1 cup strong coffee or water, cooled
1 cup buttermilk or sour milk or non dairy ‘milk’
1/2 cup unflavoured vegetable oil
1 tsp pure vanilla extract
ganache icing:
1 1/2 cups whipping cream
12 oz semisweet chocolate by weight, chopped
1 tsp pure vanilla extract  Method 1.  Preheat oven to 350F. Butter 2  8 or 9 inch round cake pans and line the bottoms with parchment paper.
2.  In a large bowl sift together flour, sugars, cocoa powder, baking soda, baking powder and salt. Whisk to combine.
3.  In a separate bowl whisk together eggs, coffee, buttermilk, oil and vanilla.
4.  Pour wet ingredients over dry ingredients and stir until combined. Divide batter equally between the prepared pans.
5.  Bake 25 to 35 minutes or until a cake tester inserted in the middle comes out clean, or an instant read thermometer registers 185F. Cool on a rack for 10 to 15 minutes. Invert onto the rack. Remove paper liner and cool completely before icing. 
6.  For ganache icing heat the whipping cream until it just barely comes to a boil. Have chopped chocolate in another bowl and pour cream on top. Shake bowl so cream is covering chocolate. Cover bowl loosely. Let rest 4 to 5 minutes. Stir until smooth. Stir in vanilla.  Place on a rack, stirring often, cool until thick and spreadable.  Then spread 1 generous cup of icing over first cake layer before putting second cake layer on top. Crumb coat the cake by spreading a thin layer of icing all over the cake. Then spread the rest all over!

My cookbook gift guide! Here are my favourite new cookbooks this year. There were so many amazing books…It was hard to choose. There is definitely something for everyone on this list! 

Make Every Dish Delicious @lesleychestrman, @simonschusterca 
I have always thought Lesley was the best restaurant reviewer and now I love the way she writes about food and shares her recipes.

You are Human and You Need Cake @DinnerwithJulie
Calgary's most beloved cook, Julie's new book is full of delicious, easy cake recipes peppered with her wonderful no nonsense baking style and sense of humour. 

Ottolenghi Test Kitchen: Extra Good Things @noorishbynoor  & @ottolenghi  @appetite_randomhouse
Yotam Ottolenghi continues to offer delicious recipes that inspire and introduce new flavours that give your food that extra edge. And great that he promotes the amazing talent in his test kitchen.

Slow Cooked: An Unexpected Life In Food Politics @marionnestle @uc_press 
For everyone interested in nutrition and common sense, it is amazing to read the journey of how Marion Nestle became Marion Nestle, the most respected nutritionist of our time.

Smitten Kitchen Keepers by Deb Perelman @smittenkitchen @appetite_randomhouse
The book everyone on social media has been looking forward to. And that's a lot of people! Me too.

Cannelle et Vanille Bakes Simple by Aran Goyoaga @cannellevanille
The very best gluten free book I have seen. There is even an amazing braided challah recipe. 

Jacques Pepin Art of the Chicken @jacquespepinfoundation
Jacques' new cookbook brings back memories of when he taught  at my cooking school. When we did market classes he  drew and illustrated the menus and his book really shows his talents as a chef and as an artist.

What’s for Dessert @csaffitz @carksonpotter
Claire Saffitz's second book is just as exciting as her first and on every dessert person's must have list!

Treasures of the Mexican Table @patijinich @houghtonmifflinharcourt
If you love Mexican food you cannot resist the joy in Pati's recipes and her James Beard award winning PBS series Pati's Mexican Table. [Caption continued in comments]

Chewy Ginger Spice Cookies are a perfect cookie to make when you’re sitting at home during a snowstorm! They’ll warm you right up. This is one of the best ginger cookie recipes I know, originally from Marianne Saunders in Calgary.

Ingredients
1/2 cup butter
1 cup granulated sugar
1 egg
1/4 cup molasses
1 1/2 tbsp strong prepared coffee or tea
2 cups all-purpose flour or gf flour (I used @cup4cup)
1 tsp baking soda
1/2 tsp kosher salt
1 tsp ground cinnamon
1 tsp ground ginger
1/2 tsp ground cloves
1/2 cup raisins
1/2 cup chopped dried apricots
1/4 cup chopped candied ginger
2 tbsp coarse sugar

Method
1.  Line two rimmed 12"x18" baking sheets with parchment paper. About 1/2 hour before baking preheat oven to 350F.
2.  In a large bowl with an electric mixer or in a food processor cream butter with sugar until light. Beat in egg, molasses and coffee.
3.  In a separate bowl, whisk together flour, baking soda, salt, cinnamon, ginger and cloves. Stir into butter mixture and add raisins, apricots and ginger. Refrigerate one to two hours.
4.  Divide dough into four equal pieces. Roll each piece into a log about 14" long and 1" wide. If dough is sticky lightly flour your hands and work surface. Place two logs on each sheet pan leaving space between (they will spread). Flatten the rolls. Sprinkle generously with coarse sugar and press in gently.
5.  Bake 10 to 14 minutes - cookies should still be soft but a little crusty on the surface. Remove the cookies from the sheet pans with the parchment paper. Let cool a few minutes. Cut on the diagonal into 1" slices. Cool.
approximately 50 to 60 cookies

Christmas Morning Panettone French Toast

Leftover panettone is so delicious when made into French Toast (or should I say Italian French Toast). You can also use this French toast recipe with challah bread.

Ingredients
8 not-giant slices of panettone (about 3/4” to 1” thick)
4 eggs
1/2 cup milk or cream
1 tsp vanilla extract or paste
1/2 tsp ground cinnamon, optional
1 to 2 tbsp butter
maple syrup
berries

Method
1.  Preheat oven to 400F. Line a baking sheet with parchment paper.
2.  In a 9”x13” baking pan whisk 4 eggs with milk or cream. Whisk in vanilla and cinnamon (if using). Add the panettone slices and let soak 3 or 4 minutes. Turn bread over and let soak a few more minutes. Bread should have absorbed almost all the egg mixture.
3.  Heat 1 tbsp butter in a large-ish non-stick pan on medium heat until melted and sizzling. Add slices of soaked panettone carefully - they sometimes fall apart a little. Cook 2 to 3 minutes or until browned, carefully turn over and cook the second side until brown. Repeat until all the panettone is browned.
4.  Transfer to the lined baking pan and bake 5 to 10 minutes until puffed.
Makes 4 servings

Anna’s Smoked Trout Spread

If you’re in need of a New Year’ Eve appetizer (or an any time appetizer) this might just be it. Anna based this on my whitefish spread in "Essentials of Home Cooking" (which is based on the smoked whitefish dips I love at @schmaltzappetizing and the one at @unitedbakers ). It is so easy and delicious and best of all everyone loves it. It’s great as a filling for party sandwiches, or as a dip with veggies or chips, spread it on crostini or use as a topping for potato latkes or vegetable pancakes.

Ingredients
8 oz smoked trout or whitefish (bones and skin removed), and flaked
2 tbsp chopped fresh dill
1 tbsp chopped fresh chives or green onions
1/4 to 1/3 cup mayonnaise
1 tbsp lemon juice
pepper and maybe salt to taste (probably won't need salt)

Method
1.  Combine flaked fish in a mixing bowl with dill, chives or green onions and mayonnaise. Add lemon juice and pepper to taste. Add salt only if necessary.
makes about 1 cup

My favourite way to cook bacon! This might come in handy if you’re also thinking about a New Year’s Day brunch. I love @cumbraes double smoked thick bacon (10 to 12 slices per pound) - it is truly my favourite. Preheat your oven to 400F.  Line an 12”x18” baking sheet with aluminum foil and place a cookie rack on top. Arrange bacon in a single layer on the rack - slices can be touching but try not to overlap them. Brush bacon with a light coating of maple syrup (optional but so good). Bake for 20 to 25 minutes or longer until bacon is a crisp as you like it. Remove from oven and leave bacon to drain on the rack about 10 minutes longer. #bacon #dontworryjustcook #brunch #cookingtip

Chocolate Soufflé Roulade with Coffee Caramel Cream

This elegant rolled souffle cake is just as delicious now as when I started making it years and years ago. Don’t worry about rolling it up - if it cracks a bit it will still look and taste great and remember - it can always be a trifle served from a pretty bowl! Serve with chocolate or caramel sauce but also delicious on its own.

Ingredients
cake:
6 eggs, separated
3/4 cup sugar, divided
1/3 cup unsweetened cocoa, sifted
1 tsp vanilla extract
2 tbsp icing sugar or cocoa, sifted
filling:
3/4 cup whipping cream, very cold
2 tbsp icing sugar, sifted
1 tsp instant espresso powder or finely ground instant coffee
about 1/2 cup chopped chocolate coated caramel bars. 
1.  Butter or spray a 9”x13” sheet pan and line with parchment paper. Preheat oven to 350F.
2.  In a large bowl with a whisk or electric mixer beat egg yolks with 1/2 cup of the sugar until light and thick. Beat in cocoa and vanilla.
3.  In a clean bowl with clean beaters whip egg whites until they turn white and slowly add remaining 1/4 cup sugar. Continue beating until stiff peaks form.
4.  Stir about 1/4 of the whites into the cocoa mixture to lighten it and then fold in the remaining egg whites.
5.  Spread souffle mixture evenly over the prepared pan and bake 14 to 16 minutes until puffed and top feels firm and dry. Cool in pan on a rack (souffle will fall) at least 15 minutes. Dust top of cake with cocoa or icing sugar and loosen from the edges of the pan. Invert onto another piece of parchment paper. Cool completely.
6.  Whip cream in a large bowl and when it starts to thicken beat in icing sugar and espresso powder. Spread cream evenly over the cooled cake and sprinkle with chopped caramel bars.
7.  Roll up cake (lengthwise for a long thin cake or widthwise for a pudgier cake) using the parchment paper to help you roll and then gently roll onto a serving plate. Refrigerate until ready to serve.
Serves 8 #chocolate #roulade #souffle #dontworryjustcook #scorebars #dessert

Charmoula
I asked Anna what we should say about charmoula in our book “Don’t Worry, Just Cook” and her response was, “what is there to say about our magic everything sauce?” I think that adequately describes how we feel about this version of charmoula. Traditionally, charmoula is a spicy Moroccan sauce that is olive oil based and often used on fish. We on the other hand make it this way and use it on everything.

Ingredients
1 cup mayonnaise
1 clove garlic, grated or minced
1/2 to 1 tsp ground cumin, preferably roasted
1 tsp pureed chipotle chilies (canned) or Tabasco chipotle
2 tbsp lemon juice
1/2 tsp smoked paprika
2 tbsp chopped fresh cilantro

Method - Combine mayonnaise with garlic, cumin, chipotles, lemon juice, paprika and cilantro. Season to taste.
Makes approximately one cup

Winter Hot Chocolate ⛄️ Here’s the easiest, quickest hot chocolate recipe ever! You can use cooking chocolate, chocolate chips or broken up chocolate bars. If you like it less sweet use bittersweet (not unsweetened!) chocolate. For a less rich version use part water, part milk. For a richer version use part cream and part milk. If you have leftovers -  reheat gently.
 
Ingredients
2 cups milk 
4 to 6 oz semisweet chocolate, in small pieces
1 tsp pure vanilla extract
approximately 24 miniature marshmallows
cinnamon sticks, optional
 
Method

1. Microwave: Heat milk in a 4-cup glass measuring cup on High for 3 to 4 minutes or until milk is very hot. Pour over chocolate, cover let rest 2 to 3 minutes. Whisk gently until smooth. 

or:
        Conventional method: Place milk in a medium sized saucepan on medium heat until milk is almost at a boil. Add chocolate and whisk gently until chocolate is completely melted and combined. Mixture should be hot - reheat gently over low heat, stirring, if it has cool down a bit.

Either method be careful as chocolate (and milk) burn easily and milk can boil over easily.
	
2. Whisk in vanilla. Taste and add a bit more chocolate if necessary.
	
3. Place marshmallows in the mugs and pour in hot chocolate mixture. (Add a cinnamon stick if you have one as a stirrer.) Or, place marshmallows on top and carefully  torch marshmallows with a blow torch.
Makes 4 servings

I love steaks cooked on the barbecue, but that can be hard to accomplish at home in the middle of winter. But you might be surprised that a pan-seared steak is so delicious. Note: I okayed Anna using this photo, but please know the steaks are more crowded than I would advise for browning and these were very special occasion Rib steaks!! You should have a good digital meat thermometer to prevent overcooking. Herbs are optional. (I roughly followed the method on Serious Eats - but finished it in the oven. )

Ingredients
2 steaks (sirloin, Rib steak, any tender cut), about 2" thick and at least 1 lb/500g each
kosher salt
1 tbsp extra virgin olive oil or vegetable oil
freshly ground black pepper
2 large whole cloves garlic
4 sprigs fresh thyme
2 sprigs fresh rosemary
2 tbsp butter, optional 

Method
1.  Season steaks generously with kosher salt at least one hour before cooking or up to overnight in the refrigerator. Remove steaks from refrigerator about one hour before cooking.
2.  Preheat oven to 400F.
3.  Brush a large-ish cast iron or heavy skillet with oil on high heat until very hot. Heat until smoking. Add steaks and cook 4 to 5 minutes until well browned, turn and cook 2nd side 4 to 5 minutes. (Also brown the edges - kind of standing the steak up - for a minute or two until browned.) I browned these two steaks separately as my pan was a little small for both but then transferred them to the oven in the same pan.
4.  Add garlic, herbs and butter, if using to the pan. Baste steaks. Transfer to the oven and finish the cooking 5 to 10 minutes longer or until a digital thermometre reads 120F for rare or 130F for medium rare to medium when inserted into the middle of the thickest part.
5.  Remove from oven, transfer steaks to a carving board and allow to rest  5 to 10 minutes. To carve, carve meat from the bone and then carve crosswise. (Take bids for the bones.)
Makes 4 to 6 servings

In a Zoom class recently I was cutting up oranges and lots of people found it to be a very helpful tip! So I’m sharing it with you too! The best way to peel an orange is to cut off both ends (so both ends are flat) and then stand the orange up on one end and cut off the peel by following the sides downwards until all the peel is gone. It’s helpful to try and get most of the pith too as many people@find it bitter. Then you can slice the orange into rounds that are beautiful on salads, or to make a whole orange salad or dessert. If you can get different kinds of oranges - here I’m using CaraCara and you could add blood oranges and navel oranges and the array of colours is beautiful. The other way to cut an orange (peel the same way) is into segments or the fancy word - supremes. This is the ultimate luxury of citrus slicing (says @acrupert ) where you cut between the membranes to reveal just the flesh of the orange. These can also be added to salads, be used to decorate desserts like rice pudding or ice cream. But be sure to keep the membranes - not only are they delicious but there is likely lots of juice left to drink and the membranes have fibre. Oranges can be a ray of sunshine when in Toronto at least it’s been very grey lately! Enjoy! #oranges #citrus #supremes

Roasted Butternut Squash with Penne and Hazelnuts

I made this for dinner one night with ingredients on hand and it turned into a delicious easy winter recipe.

Ingredients
1 lb butternut squash, peeled and cut into chunks
1 red onion, halved, peeled and thickly sliced
1 large clove garlic, peeled and quartered
3 tbsp extra virgin olive oil
1 tbsp maple syrup or honey
1 tsp kosher salt
a few sprigs of thyme
1/2 lb penne or other tubular pasta
1 tbsp butter, diced, optional
kosher salt and freshly ground black pepper
handful baby spinach or arugula
1/4 cup ricotta, goat cheese or labaneh, optional
2 tbsp chopped roasted hazelnuts
1 tbsp coarsely chopped fresh Italian parsley

Method
1.  Preheat over to 425F. Line a baking sheet with parchment paper.  Place squash, onions and garlic on the parchment and drizzle with olive oil, maple syrup, salt and thyme. Spread over the baking sheet and roast for 35 to 40 minutes or until the the squash and onions brown.
2.  Bring a large saucepan of water to a boil. Add about 1 tbsp kosher salt. When squash is almost ready add the pasta and cook until 10 to 12  minutes or until just tender.
3.  Drain pasta and place on the pan with vegetables. Add spinach, butter and some salt and pepper to taste. Toss. Top with ricotta and sprinkle with hazelnuts and parsley.
Makes 2 to 3 servings #pasta #easydinner #dontworryjustcook #squash #hazelnuts #yum

Hazelnut Buttercrunch

This is a homemade version of the caramel chocolate bars that I love to chop up, fold into whipped cream and use as a filling or topping for cakes (kinda like a skor bar). It can also be cut into chunks and eaten as a treat or sprinkled on cakes as a decoration. Roast hazelnuts by spreading them on a baking sheet and baking in a preheated 350F oven for 15 to 20 minutes until lightly browned. After roasting, rub warm hazelnuts with a tea towel and remove as much of the skins as possible. Other nuts can also be used.
Have ingredients and equipment ready before you start and read the recipe thoroughly.

Ingredients
1/2 cup butter
1 1/4 cups granulated sugar
2 tbsp water
1 tbsp corn syrup
1/2 tsp kosher salt
1/2 tsp baking soda
1 cup coarsely chopped toasted hazelnuts
4 oz semisweet or bittersweet chocolate, chopped
1/2 cup finely chopped toasted hazelnuts
1 tsp flaky sea salt, optional

Method
1.  Line a 12"x18" baking sheet with parchment paper. Have another piece of parchment paper handy and a smallish rolling pin.
2.  Place butter in medium sized heavy saucepan and melt on medium heat. Stir in sugar, water, corn syrup and salt and cook, stirring until sugar dissolves. Increase heat to medium-high and cook, stirring often,  until an instant read or candy thermometre reaches 300F - about 5 minutes. Mixture will have turned golden brown. Add baking soda (mixture will froth up a bit) and cook another minute but if it looks like it is getting too dark remove from heat and continue. Stir in 1 cup hazelnuts and quickly spread the mixture over the parchment paper lined baking sheet. Spread as thin as possible, cover with the second piece of parchment and with the rolling pin roll top of buttercrunch to spread it further or even it out.
3.  Remove second sheet of parchment paper and sprinkle chopped chocolate all over the buttercrunch (or leave some plain). Let sit a few minutes to melt from the heat of the buttercrunch. Sprinkle with finely chopped nuts and salt if using. Refrigerate an hour or two or longer at room temperature until chocolate sets.
4.  Remove from pan and chop as you wish. Store in a sealed container.
Makes lots but it goes fast.

Winter Roast Potato Salad

Although winter in Tel Aviv isn’t anything like winter in Toronto, the idea for this winter potato salad came from a meal, in ‘winter’, at Port Said, one of our favourite places in Tel Aviv. (We were eating outside so you can imagine what winter is like there.) We’re biased but think this is so delicious!

Ingredients
3 lbs Yukon Gold potatoes, cut into about 1 1/2 inch pieces
1 red onion, halved and sliced
2 tbsp extra virgin olive oil
1 tsp kosher salt
freshly ground black pepper to taste
1 bunch broccolini or 1/2 bunch broccoli, florets and stems separated
3 green onions, halved lengthwise or cut into 2 inch lengths
dressing:
2 tbsp sherry vinegar
1 tsp Dijon mustard
1 tsp honey
1 small clove garlic, minced or grated
1/2 tsp kosher salt
1/3 cup extra virgin olive oil or to taste
2 tbsp chopped fresh dill

Method
1.  Preheat oven to 425F. Line a baking sheet with parchment paper.
2.  Place potatoes and onions on sheet pan and toss with olive oil, salt and pepper. Roast 20 minutes or until potatoes are starting to brown. Add stems of broccolini and roast 10 minutes longer. Add florets and green onions and roast 10 minutes longer.
3.  While potatoes are roasting prepare dressing in a food processor or blender by processing all ingredients including oil, or in a bowl with a whisk, whisk vinegar, mustard, honey, garlic and salt together. Whisk in oil until combined and slightly thickened. In either case taste dressing and adjust seasoning if needed.
4.  When potatoes and vegetables are ready, drizzle half the dressing over everything on the baking sheet, sprinkle with dill and toss. Taste and add more dressing if necessary. Otherwise it will keep in the fridge for a few weeks. Serve on baking sheet for a casual look or transfer to a shallow serving bowl.
Makes 6 to 8 servings #potatoes #potatosalad #yum

Winter Day Pumpkin and Leek Soup 

We just got back from Israel where it was winter, but nothing like Canada’s winter. On the trip though we were lucky enough to have lunch with @gilhovavisrael and Dvora Frishberg at @rutenberg_restaurant a beloved Israeli restaurant on the border of Israel and Jordan just south of the Sea of Galilee. The setting was beautiful and we could see Jordan across the river. We had a wonderful lunch and I adapted their hearty and delicious soup to warm us up upon our return to snowy Canadian winter! We also got to use our new bowls from @ronityampottery - making our dinner extra special. I think you should make this and warm up with this too. 
Notes: When a recipe calls for pumpkin I usually substitute butternut squash for the right texture and colour. To trim leeks, cut away the tougher dark green tops and use the lightly green and white parts. Be sure to rinse out any sand in the layers before or after slicing.

Ingredients
2 tbsp extra virgin olive oil
1 lb leeks, (2 large) trimmed, and rinsed well and sliced (about 1 cup)
2 large cloves garlic, chopped
1 tsp crushed or ground coriander seeds
1 1/2 lbs butternut squash, peeled and cut into chunks
1 lb parsnips, peeled and cut into chunks
4 cups chicken or vegetable stock or water
kosher salt and freshly ground black pepper
toppings:
1/4 toasted pumpkin seeds
1 1/2 tsp sumac
1/4 cup crumbled feta or goat cheese, optional

Method
1.  Heat oil in a large saucepan and add leeks. Cook gently 3 or 4 minutes until softened. Add garlic and coriander and cook 2 minutes longer.
2.  Add squash and parsnips (you should have about 6 cups) and combine. Add stock or water and bring to a boil. Add 1 tsp salt and a little pepper. Reduce heat and cook 25 to 35 minutes until vegetables are very tender.
3.  Puree soup with an immersion blender or in a food processor or blender until smooth. Season to taste. If soup is too thick thin with a little boiling water and adjust season.
4.  Top each serving with pumpkin seeds, sumac and crumbled cheese if using.
Makes 6 servings #soup #wintercooking #pumpkin #leeks #dontworryjustcook #delicious

Chocolate mousse is back. I love it with whipped cream and crushed praline but it is also great with caramel sauce, meringues, berries, chopped candy bars and halvah.
Note: When separating eggs be sure your hands are clean and dry and that the bowl the egg whites are going into is clean and dry and that no yolk gets into the whites.
When melting chocolate to avoid burning or over heating, melt as directed below until just a few small pieces remain and then stir to finish melting.

Ingredients
8 oz semisweet chocolate (by weight), chopped
1/4 cup butter, cut into small chunks
2 tbsp strong prepared coffee (reg or decaf) or brandy or favourite liqueur, optional
1 tbsp pure vanilla extract or paste
4 eggs, separated yolks from whites
1/2 cup sugar
1/2 cup whipping cream
flaked sea salt

Method
1.  Melt chocolate in the microwave for 2 minutes on high and then at 30 seconds intervals until almost completely melted. Stir to finish the melting. Or melt chocolate in a bowl set over (not in) gently simmering water until almost completely melted and stir, off heat, to finish melting.
2.  Whisk in butter, bit by bit, then coffee and vanilla and stir until smooth.
3.  Using a whisk, beat egg yolks into chocolate.
4.  With a hand mixer beat cream until light and soft - but not firm. Reserve.
5.  Wash beaters and beat egg whites until opaque and foamy. Add sugar gradually and beat until soft to medium peaks form. Stir a big spoonful of whites into chocolate to lighten it and then gently fold in remaining whites and gently fold in reserved whipped cream. Spoon mixture into individual serving bowls/cups/glasses and sprinkle with coarse salt before refrigerating, at least a few hours before serving.
Makes about 6 to 8 servings #chocolate #chocolatemousse #telaviv #dontworryjustcook #motherdaughtercooking #yum

Hamantaschen Tips!

Everyone has their own favourite hamantaschen recipe for Purim - which begins tomorrow night. Two of my favourites are recipes from @urischeft @lehamimbakery in his book Breaking Breads and from @leah.koenig in her book The Jewish Cookbook. Hamantaschen are triangular shaped individual pastries filled with any number of fillings - both sweet and savory. These general tips that will help you with any recipe! 
1.  Roll your dough and shape your hamantaschen when you first make the dough because it will be more pliable and break less (vs trying to roll and shape cold dough). But be sure to cover them and refrigerate a few hours (or freeze) before baking so they hold their shape.
2.  To prevent breaking and overflowing, do not overfill your hamantaschen! I know it is so hard not to add more filling but try to control ourselves.
3.  To prevent the three corners from opening up when baking, use cold water to pinch all corners together firmly. And then pinch again. And even again.
4.  Brush with egg wash and if they are sweet sprinkle with coarse sugar. #hamantaschen #purim #cookingtips

Tuna Salad with Preserved Lemon and Herbs 

I sat in the back of @caffetamati in Tel Aviv, talking to the owner, Mickey, as he made a huge batch of tuna salad for sandwiches. He said our mutual friend, @adeenasussman gave him the tip of using preserved lemon paste in the mix. It was a delicious tip and now I do it too. I lost track of everything else he was doing (so excited about the preserved lemons) so here's my version. You can buy preserved lemons (or preserved lemon paste) in Middle Eastern shops or specialty shops or you can make your own preserved lemons by layering sliced or chunky pieces of lemon with kosher salt in a preserving jar - there's a recipe in my new cookbook 'Don't Worry, Just Cook' (that I wrote with my daughter @acrupert ).

Ingredients
7oz can tuna, preferably packed in olive oil
2 ribs celery, halved lengthwise and chopped
2 tbsp finely chopped preserved lemons (rinsed before chopping) or preserved lemon paste
1/2 cup chopped fresh herbs (I use a combination of cilantro, parsley and dill)
5 tbsp mayonnaise (I use Hellman's Real) or to taste
kosher salt and freshly ground black pepper to taste

Method
1.  Drain tuna well. Break it apart in a mixing bowl and add the celery and preserved lemon. Mix well. Add the herbs and stir to combine.
2.  Add the mayonnaise, mix well and season to taste.
3.  Serve as a salad or make into 3 to 4 sandwiches on fresh buns or challah with arugula or preferred lettuce.
Makes about 2 cups #tuna #tunasalad #lunch #preservedlemons

Caramelized Matzah Crunch
Passover would not be complete without this irresistible treat. I have been making this for about 25 years and got the recipe from my friend Mitchell @kitchensense who got it from his sister in Toronto who got it from her friend and you know the rest. But it was Marcy Goldman, Montreal cookbook author, who was the original creator and it has become a Passover tradition everywhere. There are many ways to decorate it and it has many names but it is otherwise mostly the same.  Ingredients
5 to 6 pieces matzah (about 7-inch x 6-inch )
1 cup butter, cut into pieces
1 cup packed brown sugar
2 cups chopped semisweet or bittersweet chocolate or chocolate chips (3/4 lb chocolate)
1 to 2 tsp flaked sea salt
2 oz white or milk chocolate, chopped and melted, optional
or
2 cups toasted chopped or sliced almonds, chopped toasted hazelnuts or toasted coconut chips or chopped candy bars or sprinkles
Method
1. Preheat oven to 350F. Line a large, 12-inch x 18-inch sheet pan with aluminum foil. Arrange matzah on foil in a single layer - don’t worry if it overlaps a little.
2. Place butter and brown sugar in a medium saucepan and bring to a boil. Cook for 3 minutes, stirring constantly.  Pour mixture over the matzah. Spread as evenly as possible. Bake for 15 to 18  minutes or until mixture is bubbling and browning a bit around the edges and on top (do not let it burn).
3. As soon as matzah comes out of the oven sprinkle with chopped chocolate. After 4 to 5 minutes spread chocolate as evenly as possible - the chocolate will melt from the heat of the matzah.  Sprinkle with salt. Drizzle chocolate with melted white (or milk) chocolate or sprinkle with toasted nuts etc.  4. Chill until the chocolate and caramel are set. Remove from refrigerator before cutting into squares- ish pieces. Cut while very cold (or even frozen) with a hot knife. Store in refrigerator. Freezes well - if chocolate gets white streaks it is still delicious and safe to eat.
Makes how much? There’s never enough
#matzah #matzahcrunch #caramel #chocolate #passover #passoverrecipes #motherdaughtercooking

There are so many delicious variations of matzah crunch! In my last reel I showed you how to make matzah crunch with caramel, chocolate and roasted hazelnuts. But you can use any kind of chocolate or mix and swirl different kinds into beautiful patterns. Or you can leave the chocolate off all together and add your toppings right onto the caramel. Instead of hazelnuts you could use chopped roasted almonds or pecans or coconut chips. You could add sprinkles or even your favourite candy! And a very beautiful option is white chocolate with pistachios and pomegranate seeds. Watch the reel to see some photos at the end. And tell us what your favourite matzah crunch toppings are in the comments!! #matzah #matzahcrunch #passover

Ruthie’s Fried Matzah (Matzah Brei)

You asked and we’ve delivered! Fried matzah, matzah brei or sometimes even Passover French toast, can be eaten plain (my preference) or sweet with a little cinnamon sugar on top (Anna’s) and some people don’t like it at all (but who??) It’s great with added caramelized onions or fried onions and mushrooms - cook them first and then stir into the fried maztah towards the end to reheat. Note: if you’re using gluten free matzah it tends to get soggy faster than regular matzah when you add the boiling water so be careful not to soak too long. 

For 2 to 3 people, break up 4 pieces of matzah into approximately 1” to 1 1/2” pieces. Place in a strainer set over a bowl. Boil water (about 6 to 8 cups) and pour over matzah in the strainer in the bowl. Let matzah soak for about 20 seconds in the bowl. Lift out the strainer with the matzah and press down with the back of a spoon to get out excess liquid.

In a clean bowl beat 3 or 4 eggs together with salt (and pepper if eating plain or savoury) and add the drained matzah pieces. Stir it around and let the matzah soak up the eggs, about 3 to 4 minutes. Meanwhile heat a 9” or 10” non stick pan, add 2 tbsp vegetable oil or schmaltz (chicken/duck fat) and add matzah, spreading it around the pan. Break matzah pieces up with a wooden spoon and fry, stirring and turning often until the level of soggy or crispness you prefer (@raymondrupert likes it soggy so I take some out for him first and then continue cooking the rest for me!) We love this even when it’s not Passover. #matzah #friedmatzah #matzahbrei #passoverrecipes #motherdaughtercooking

Gil’s Yemenite Beef Stew

@gilhovavisrael is well known in Israel as a tv personality, chef, journalist, author and storyteller. I am lucky to call him a good friend and when I am in Israel he cooks something SO delicious. Most recently this amazing stew called Mahshoush. If you are looking for an Easter or Passover main this is it! Hawaiij is a Yemenite spice blend - there is a savory blend for soup/stews, and a sweeter blend for coffee. I make my own - see the recipe in Don't Worry Just Cook - or buy. 
Ingredients
4 - 5 lbs shoulder beef, cut into 1 1/2" chunks (sometimes called blade or chuck)
kosher salt, freshly ground black pepper
1/2 cup all-purpose flour (or gf flour), optional (omit for Passover)
1/4 cup extra virgin olive oil or more as needed
2 lbs potatoes, peeled and cut into chunks
1 lb carrots, peeled and cut into chunks
6 onions, halved, peeled and chopped
12 cloves garlic, chopped
2 tbsp hawaiij spice mix
1/4 cup chopped fresh cilantro or parsley

Method
1. Pat chunks of beef dry. Season generously with salt and pepper, dust with flour.
2. Heat 2 tbsp oil in a large non stick pan or Dutch oven. Brown chunks of meat on all sides in batches until well browned. Add oil as necessary. Remove from pan. Brown potatoes and then carrots. As they brown remove and add to meat. Remove and discard all but 2 tbsp oil from pan and add onions. Cook on medium-low heat until browned, tender and fragrant. Add garlic and cook a few minutes longer. At any point if pan seems dry, add 1/4 cup water and scrape any delicious bits of meat or vegetables off the bottom of the pan into the onions. Onions should be browned.
3. Add hawaiij to onions and cook a minute. Add beef, potatoes and carrots and combine well. Cover top of meat and vegetables directly with parchment paper and then a tight fitting lid or aluminum foil.
4. Cook in preheated 325F oven for 3 to 4 hours or until beef is meltingly tender - check every 1/2 hour to be sure meat isn't dry (all ovens are different) - if pan is dry add 1 cup water, stir, cover again with parchment paper and lid and proceed. Season to taste  with salt and pepper and sprinkle with cilantro or parsley.
Serves 8 to 10 #beefstew #yum

Chocolate Cloud Cake (aka Fallen Chocolate Souffle Cake)

All the ‘chocolate cloud cakes’ on social media recently reminded me of Richard Sax’s cake in his 1994 cookbook “Classic Home Desserts”. I like to call it a Fallen Chocolate Souffle Cake because, back then anyway, everyone was afraid their souffle would fall so they never made them. But souffles always fall! The trick is to serve them before they do (right out of the oven!) or let them fall and serve them at room temperature like this cake. Whatever you call it, it will be a hit and perfect for Passover (it flourless), Easter or any special dinner.

Ingredients
1/2 lb semisweet or bittersweet chocolate, chopped
1/2 cup butter, in small pieces
2 whole eggs
4 eggs, separated
3/4 cup sugar - divided
1 tbsp pure vanilla extract or paste, optional
topping:
1 1/2 cup whipping cream, cold
2 tbsp icing sugar, sifted
2 tsp pure vanilla extract or paste
shaved chocolate (I use chopped Skor bars)

Method
1. Preheat oven to 350F. Line 8” springform pan with parchment paper - do not butter or spray.
2. Melt chocolate and butter in a medium glass bowl (clean and dry) for 2 minutes in the microwave. Stir to finish melting.
3. In another bowl beat the 2 whole eggs with 4 yolks and about half the sugar until smooth. Beat in the chocolate. Stir in the vanilla.
4. In a clean and dry bowl, beat egg whites until white and foamy. Slowly beat in remaining half of the sugar and continue beating until light and soft peaks form. Stir about 1/4 whites into chocolate/egg yolk mixture and then gently fold in the remaining whites. Transfer to prepared pan and bake 35 to 40 minutes.
5. When souffle has puffed but still slightly moist in the centre, cool on a rack. The souffle will fall and sometimes forms a bowl like shape in the centre (don’t worry - that’s where the cream goes.) Cool completely.
6. Just before serving whip cream with icing sugar and vanilla until very light but not too stiff and spoon into centre of the souffle. Sprinkle with chocolate.
serves 8 #chocolate #souffle #cloudcake #passoverrecipes #easterrecipes

Frozen Lemon Meringue Cake

One of my insta followers reminded me of a frozen lemon meringue cake I used to make years ago for Passover I decided to revive it!

Ingredients
8 egg whites (use the yolks below)
1/2 tsp cream of tartar
1 3/4 cups fruit/instant dissolving or granulated sugar
1 tbsp cornstarch or potato starch
lemon curd:
3/4 cup sugar
finely grated zest from one lemon
1 cup freshly squeezed lemon juice
8 egg yolks
1/2 cup butter, in small pieces
1 1/2 cups whipping cream
Method
1. For meringue, preheat oven to 275F. Line 2 baking sheets with parchment paper and trace four 8" circles, two per sheet - marked side of parchment facing down. Beat egg whites and cream of tartar in a stand mixer with balloon whisk until frothy and opaque about 1-2 mins. Keep beating as you add sugar very gradually, then keep beating until very firm and light. Sift cornstarch over top and gently fold in. Spread evenly over the 4 circles. Bake for 1 - 1 1/2 hours until crunchy throughout. Do not worry if they brown a little or if slightly soft.Turn off oven and let cool in oven and dry out. This can be done a day ahead. Once dried out, store in a cool dry place or in the freezer.
2. For lemon curd bring sugar, zest and lemon juice to a boil in a saucepan. Cook gently until sugar dissolves. Mix egg yolks in a mixing bowl, whisk in lemon juice mixture. Return mixture to saucepan and cook gently, stirring, until mixture just comes to a boil and thickens. Whisk in pieces of butter on very low heat, until butter has melted. Strain into a bowl, cool, cover surface directly with plastic wrap and refrigerate.
3. Whip cream just before assembling and fold into the lemon curd.
4. To assemble cake, save the most uneven meringue for the end. Place one meringue on a serving platter. Spread one cup lemon cream mixture over it. Top with another meringue, lemon cream and a third meringue. Spread remaining lemon cream over top and sides. Crush remaining meringue into pieces and sprinkle over the top. Dust with icing sugar. Freeze. Serve frozen (remove from freezer about 15 minutes before serving
Makes 10 to 12 servings

Anna & Bonnie’s Fried Matzah Grilled Cheese Omelet Sandwich

This is a cross between a cheese omelet and grilled cheese sandwich and friend matzah all of which I love. Prepare 1/2 recipe of fried matzah (recipe in previous friend matzah post). I like to add about 1/2 tsp chipotle chile sauce or any hot sauce and 1 tbsp chopped fresh cilantro to the eggs. Cook the matzah in a pan flat in one big piece. When it is cooked on the bottom, reduce heat to cook it a bit longer. When the egg on the top side is just barely cooked sprinkle the top with the about 2 oz grated or sliced cheese (I like smoked or regular Cheddar). Flip one side over the other side and continue cooking gently until cheese melts.

You could also use the flat fried matzah as a base for pizza and other types of sandwiches or frittatas. You can fold it or leave it open faced! And you can use any/all toppings that you like. #yum  #passoverrecipes #matzah

Caramelized Onion and Creamy Cheese Matzah Pizza

When I wanted to make a Passover pizza, my daughter @acrupert suggested adapting one of our favourite recipes from my cookbook Essentials of Home Cooking (no wonder she is now my co-author!) Use other cheese or other herbs as you wish. But trust us this is so delicious as is!!
Ingredients
caramelized onions:
2 tbsp extra virgin olive oil or butter
3 large onions, chopped (about 1 1/2 lbs)
1 tbsp sugar (preferably brown)
1 tbsp balsamic vinegar
1/2 tsp kosher salt
1/2 tsp freshly ground black pepper
pizza:
3 or 4 pieces matzah (regular or gluten free)
4 oz Brie cheese
4 oz mild Gorgonzola or Cambozola
2 tbsp chopped fresh tarragon

Method
1. For the caramelized onions heat oil in a large deep skillet over medium high heat. Cook about 10 minutes until wilted and starting to brown. Add sugar, vinegar, salt and pepper. Reduce heat to low or medium low and cook uncovered, stirring often, for 15 to 25 minutes or until richly caramelized. Cool. You should have 3/4 to 1 cup. (You can freeze any extra.)
2. Preheat oven to 400F. Carefully break each piece of matzah in half and place on baking sheet(s).
3. Cut half of the Brie in very thin slices. Dice the remaining Brie and Gorgonzola.
4. Place the thin slices in a single layer on the matzah. Place in the oven for 2 minutes or until just melted. (This helps the onions stick on the matzah.) Spread with a thin layer of caramelized onions and top with pieces of cheese. Sprinkle with tarragon.
5. Just before serving bake in preheated 400F oven for 10 to 12 minutes or until cheese has melted and top is lightly browned. For appetizers cut each piece in half or thirds.
Serve 4 to 6 #passoverrecipes #matzahpizza #yum

Caramelized Almond Wafers

My good friend Gwen Berkowitz, one of the best cooks I have ever known, died a few years ago but not before leaving me with such delicious memories and recipes. These cookies are easy to make, very few ingredients, naturally gluten free and dairy free. And they freeze well. They are great for Passover but you should make them all the time as I do.
*Note: The secret here is not to whip up the egg whites (which everyone seems to want to do) and to use sliced almonds that look like flat wide slices.
If possible, turn off the oven and allow the cookies to cool another 15 minutes in the turned off oven. Cool and cut into squares.

Ingredients
2 egg whites
1/2 cup sugar
1/2 tsp pure vanilla extract, optional
3 cups sliced almonds

Method
1. Preheat oven to 350F. Line 2 sheet pans with parchment paper.
2. In a large bowl stir egg whites with sugar. Do not whip up - just stir together well. Add vanilla and almonds and stir to coat well.
3. Use 1 large tbsp mixture for each cookie.  Mound on prepared baking sheets. Flatten cookies with the back of the spoon and gently press cookies flat.
4.  Bake 12 to 15 minutes or until cookies are browned. Turn off oven and let cookies rest another 15 minutes with the oven door slightly open and they will be crisper.  Makes about 30 cookies #passoverrecipes #glutenfree #dairyfree #cookies #almonds

Rhubarb Cobbler Crisp

When I wanted to make a rhubarb dessert for Friday night dinner recently but the original recipe wouldn’t be enough to fit my gorgeous serving dish made by @ronityampottery, I enlarged the recipe to serve 8 to 10. I served it with amazing @rurubaked ice cream brought by a guest but vanilla or praline would work well too. It tasted like the sun was shining and that spring was around the corner. 

Ingredients
2 1/2 lbs rhubarb, trimmed and cut into 1” pieces (about 8 to 10 cups)
1/4 brown sugar
2 tbsp all-purpose flour
topping:
1 1/2 cups all-purpose flour or gluten free flour
3/4 cup rolled oats
1/2 cup toasted almonds, chopped
3/4 cup granulated sugar
3/4 cup brown sugar
3/4 tsp baking powder
1/2 tsp kosher salt
2 eggs
3/4 cup melted butter
1 1/2 tsp pure vanilla extract
3/4 tsp pure almond extract

Method
 1.  Preheat the oven to 350F. Butter or spray a 9”x13”  baking dish (or baking dish that holds about 10 to 12 cups.
2.  Combine the rhubarb with 1/4 cup brown sugar and 2 tbsp flour, then spread evenly in the prepared pan.
3.  For the topping, combine the 1 1/2 cups flour with oats, almonds, both sugars, baking powder and salt. Beat the eggs in a small bowl and with a fork or your fingers, add it to flour mixture, stirring until the mixture is crumbly. Sprinkle evenly over the fruit.
4. Combine the melted butter with the vanilla and almond extracts and drizzle as evenly as possible over the topping.
5. Bake for 45 to 50 minutes or longer until the top is golden, the fruit is juicy and tender and the kitchen smells amazing.
Makes 8 to 10 servings #rhubarb #cobbler #crisp #dontworryjustcook

Buttermilk Cornmeal Cheesy Waffles

@acrupert and I made these waffles last weekend and fell in love. We served them with extra cheese, a poached eggs and bacon. They are very versatile and I have included a number of substitutions and alternate ideas for you here - enjoy! *substitution: If you don’t have buttermilk place 1 1/2 tbsp lemon juice in a 2 cup measure and add milk up to the 1 1/2 cup mark. Rest 10 minutes before using. Or combine 3/4 cup unflavoured yogurt with 3/4 cup milk. If you are gluten free use a gf flour like Cup4Cup. If you are lactose intolerant use a lactose free cheese or omit.
*pancakes: If you do not have a waffle machine make pancakes using about 1/4 cup batter per pancake. Melt 2 tbsp butter in a nonstick pan on medium heat and cook a few minutes on one side until surface loses its shine and bubbles appear, flip and cook second side about 2 minutes until browned and cooked through.
*toppings: with maple syrup, a fried egg, guacamole, bacon, sausages, hot sauce or chile
*additions: to the batter you can add 1 tbsp chipotle puree, smoked Cheddar rather than regular Cheddar, 2 tbsp chopped fresh cilantro or dill.

Ingredients
1 1/4 cup all-purpose flour
1/2 cup cornmeal
2 tbsp sugar
2 tsp baking powder
1/2 tsp baking soda
1/2 tsp kosher salt
2 eggs
1 1/2 cups buttermilk*
1/4 cup butter, melted
1 cup (4oz) grated Cheddar cheese

Method
 1.  In one bowl whisk together flour, cornmeal, sugar, baking powder, baking soda and salt. In another bowl whisk together eggs, buttermilk and melted butter.
 2.  Stir egg mixture into flour mixture until just blended and stir in cheese.
 3.  Preheat waffle machine and preheat oven to 200F. Using 1/2 cup batter per waffle, spoon onto hot waffle machine, close the lid (it usually spreads when you close the lid) and cook on medium high 4 to 5 minutes until browned. As waffles are ready place on a baking sheet, cover lightly with parchment paper and keep warm in the oven. Repeat until all batter is used.
 4.  Served with suggested toppings.
Makes 5 to 6 waffles #waffles #cornmeal #pancakes #dontworryjustcook

Roasted Strawberries and Rhubarb with Maple Syrup and Vanilla

You know it is finally spring when there are local strawberries and rhubarb are in the markets (and soon the weather will follow!) Roasting fruit intensifies their flavour. It is so delicious for breakfast with yogurt, with scones or over ice cream for dessert. Scone recipe coming next! 
Note: If you use a vanilla bean, after cooking rinse and dry it and place in your sugar canister.

Ingredients
4  cups strawberries, hulled
1 lb rhubarb, trimmed and cut into 1” pieces
2 tbsp maple syrup
2 tbsp sugar
1 tsp pure vanilla paste or extract or a piece of vanilla bean cut open, optional

Method
1.  Preheat oven to 400F. Line a sheet pan with parchment paper.
 2.  Cut strawberries in half. If they are large cut into quarters or slice and if they are tiny, leave them whole. Spread them on the sheet pan lined with parchment paper. Mix in rhubarb. (You should have about 7 or 8 cups of fruit.)
3.  Drizzle fruit with maple syrup and sugar and toss. Drizzle with vanilla or if using a vanilla bean, bury in the fruit.
4.  Roast 20 to 30 minutes until berries cook and release an intense syrup.
makes about 1 1/2 cups #strawberries #rhubarb #dontworryjustcook #motherdaughtercooking

Coronation Scones - These are the scones I make the day of any royal celebration and are in my cookbook Don’t Worry, Just Cook that I wrote with @acrupert.  Scones are best fresh so try to make them as close to serving as possible. Make the toppings ahead - lemon curd (in the cookbook), whipped cream or creme fraiche, roasted strawberries and rhubarb etc. In the cookbook there are lots of sweet and savory variation ideas but I usually like them like this. 
Ingredients
1/2 cup very cold butter
2 cups all-purpose flour (or gluten free flour)
2 tbsp sugar
4 tsp baking powder
1/2 tsp kosher salt
1 egg
3/4 cup buttermilk (or half plain yogurt and half milk)
topping: (optional)
1 egg, lightly beaten
coarse sugar

Method
 1.  Grate cold butter carefully, on a 4-sided grater using the side you would grate Cheddar cheese (use a protective glove if possible). Freeze at least 15 minutes and use butter from frozen state. Preheat oven to 425F. Line a baking sheet with parchment paper.
 2.  Whisk flour, sugar, baking powder and salt about one minute. In another bowl beat egg with buttermilk.
 3.  Add frozen butter to the flour and disperse it quickly with your fingertips. Make a well in the centre and add egg mixture. Gently and quickly gather ingredients together to form a rough dough with your fingertips or wooden spoon. Dust your work surface lightly with flour and pat dough out to a 7” square about 3/4” to 1” thick. Fold in half, dust off any flour and gently flatten again, fold again. Repeat once more. Cut dough with a sharp knife into quarters, then cut in half on the diagonal to make 8 fairly large scones or you can cut it into 9 smaller squares or cut out circles. (If making circles, press scraps of extra dough together lightly - do not knead - and cut out again.) The less you handle the dough the better.
 4.  Place scones on a parchment paper lined sheet pan. Brush tops with egg and sprinkle with sugar, if using.
 5.  Bake in a preheated 425F oven for 12 to 14 minutes, turning pan around after about 8 minutes, until browned and puffed.
Makes about 8 or 9 scones or more smaller ones #scones #coronationcooking #dontworryjustcook

MY MOTHER’S BLINTZES
My mother, Ruthie, made the best blintzes. She was well known for this beloved Jewish food. Her bletlach (thin crepes or ‘leaves’) were very thin and the cooked blintzes were browned and buttery. In this video and recipe I tell you how she made them, or you can bake them - fill the uncooked side, roll them up with open ends and bake them  in a single layer in a buttered baking dish for 20 minutes in a preheated 375F oven. Blintzes can be assembled ahead and then cooked or frozen, or cooked and then frozen.  Ingredients
6 eggs
1 1/2 cups milk
3/4 cup water + more as needed
1 1/2 cups all-purpose flour
1 tbsp granulated sugar
1/4 tsp kosher salt
2 tbsp butter + more for cooking
filling:
1 1/2 lbs solid curd or pressed cottage (highest fat content available)
3 tbsp granulated sugar
2 eggs
pinch of salt
toppings:
sour cream or yogurt, berries, jam, compote compote

Method
 1.  In a large bowl, with a whisk or in a blender or food processor, mix together eggs, milk, water, flour, sugar and salt. Let batter rest, covered, at least 1/2 hour at room temperature or up to overnight in the refrigerator.
 2.  Melt butter in an 8 or 9 inch nonstick skillet and whisk into the batter. If batter has thickened, add additional water until it is the thickness of unwhipped whipping cream.
 3.  Return skillet to the heat (about medium or medium high) and add 1/2 cup batter. Quickly swirl batter in pan to cover the bottom and pour the rest back into the bowl of batter. Cook about a minute until the bottom has browned. (Cut off that ‘tag’ of crepe and eat it or give it to a loved one.) The first crepe is the test to see if the heat is right and help you get the swirling technique down. Stack crepes cooked side up.
 4.  For the filling combine cheese, sugar, eggs and salt. Place 2 to 3 tbsp filling in the bottom third of the crepe. Fold up the bottom, fold in the sides and roll up.
 5.  To cook, heat 2 tbsp butter in a 10 inch skillet and add blintzes about 4 to 6 at a time. Cook a few minutes per side until browned.
 6.  Serve with toppings of choice. Makes 16 blintzes #blintzes

CHUCK’S DOUBLE CHOCOLATE BROWNIES 2.0
 
These have been my favourite brownies for many years. I make small updates which just increase my love. I named these for my nephew Chuck because we sent them to him when he was in Afghanistan with the Canadian forces. He said they disappeared before he could put them on the table! (I have heard this now happens everywhere you serve them.) They are great as a brownie on their own but also delicious warm for dessert with ice cream and chocolate or caramel sauce. They freeze well so I always have some on hand for last minute gifts.
 
Ingredients
10 oz bittersweet or semisweet chocolate, chopped
1 cup butter, cut into pieces
4 eggs
1 1/2 cups sugar
1 tbsp pure vanilla extract or paste
1 cup all-purpose flour
2 tbsp cocoa (unsweetened), sifted
1 tsp baking powder
1/2 tsp kosher salt
1 cup chopped Skor bars (about 3), optional
1 cup chopped white and/or milk chocolate
1 tsp Maldon or other coarse salt, optional
 
Method 1 Preheat oven to 350F. Butter a 9”square baking dish. Line the bottom and two opposite sides with parchment paper.
2 Melt chocolate and butter together on low heat in a heavy saucepan or in the microwave (about 1 1/2 minutes). Stir until smooth. Cool. 
3 In a large mixing bowl whisk eggs until light. Whisk in sugar gradually. Keep beating until eggs are thick and pale. Add vanilla and melted chocolate/butter mixture.
4 In another bowl whisk cocoa, flour, baking powder and 1/2 tsp kosher salt. Stir into batter until completely mixed (check the bottom of the bowl.) Add skor pieces and chocolate. Spread batter in pan. Sprinkle with the coarse salt. Bake in the preheated oven 35 to 40 minutes until just set. Cool on a rack. Refrigerate at least a few hours or overnight. This will make them easier to cut nicely.
5 To remove brownie ‘cake’ in one piece for cutting, run a knife around the edge and lift it out with the parchment paper. Trim the edges (eat them or freeze for later or give them to the person you love the most because those are the best part) and cut the rest into small squares. 
Makes about 50 brownies #brownies #chocolate #dontworryjustcook #motherdaughtercooking #doublechocolate #cocoa

Grilled Flank Steak with Mustard and Worcestershire Marinade

I love flank steak. It used to be called an ‘alternative’ cut because it was a tougher cut (like hanger, skirt, flat iron or bavette) but now it is just called ‘steak’. If you cook it rare to medium rare and slice it thinly, it is tender and delicious. On the other hand, if you like your steak medium well or well-done or if you like individual steaks, use a more tender cut like filet or sirloin (although I hesitate to even recommend making steak if you like it well cooked but who am I to judge!). 

Ingredients
1 1/2  to 2 lbs flank steak
1 tsp kosher salt (I use Diamond Crystal. if not using Diamond Crystal kosher salt use half the amount)
marinade:
3 tbsp extra virgin olive oil
2 tbsp Worcestershire sauce
1 tbsp brown sugar
1 tbsp Dijon mustard
1 tbsp sherry or red wine vinegar
1  large clove garlic, grated or minced
1 tsp kosher salt
1/4 tsp freshly ground black pepper
1 tsp to 1 tbsp coarse sea salt (eg Maldon)

Method
1. Pat steak dry. Sprinkle both sides with 1 tsp salt, place in a glass baking dish or sheet pan lined with parchment paper and allow to rest in the refrigerator for a few hours or overnight. (If you forget don’t worry.)
2. For marinade combine olive oil, Worcestershire sauce, sugar, mustard, vinegar, garlic, kosher salt and pepper. Place back in pan and turn steak over and over in the marinade. Marinate steak one hour at room temperature (unless it is very hot in the kitchen) or up to a few hours in the refrigerator. 
4. Preheat barbecue. Sprinkle steak with coarse salt just before grilling. (Don’t worry that the steak will be too salty as a lot of it falls off in the cooking.) (And don’t worry if you forget to sprinkle it with salt - I often forget.) Grill 3 to 4 minutes per side until a meat thermometer reads about 125F to 130F when inserted in the middle of the thickest part. Our steak here was cooked about 7-8 minutes total. Let rest at least 5 minutes before carving into thin slices across the grain slightly on the diagonal to make wider slices.
Make 4 to 6 servings #steak #flanksteak #bbq #bbqseason #worstershire #dontworryjustcook

Sautéed Shrimp with Garlic and Chile
This dish is bright and cheery and full of flavour and if it’s been pouring rain all day for you like it has in Toronto, you don’t even need to go outside! Serve as an appetizer or for a main course over rice or pasta. You can also cook these on a hot barbecue but only cook a minute or two on each side. Either way, so simple but so good - I have been cooking shrimp this way for years and never tire of it. The original recipe came from good friend Irene Tam who is an amazing cook.
 
Ingredients
1 lb cleaned shrimp, tail on if possible (about 20)
3 tbsp extra virgin olive oil + more if necessary
2 cloves garlic, finely chopped
1/4 tsp chile flakes or more to taste
1 tsp kosher salt (Diamond Crystal)
2 tbsp chopped fresh parsley + sprigs for garnish
 
Method
Pat shrimp dry. Heat a large skillet with oil on medium heat.
Add garlic and chile flakes and cook gently until garlic is tender and fragrant but not brown.
Increase heat and add shrimp in a single layer and sprinkle with salt. In a minute or two the shrimp should start to turn pink and become opaque. Flip them and cook second side. Add parsley and stir together.
makes 6 appetizer portions or 4 mains #shrimp #garlic #chile #yum

Eton Mess
Eton Mess is a traditional English dessert that is over 100 ears old. It is said to have been first served at Eton College at an annual cricket match. Supposedly it is still sometimes served at prep school cricket matches and is always called a ‘mess’ but with the other school’s name. You can do that too. This could be called Bonnie’s Mess.
Note: Sometimes if the weather is hot and steamy meringues get sticky. If that happens re-bake them at 200F for 20 minutes or longer until dry.
 
Ingredients
meringues:
3 egg whites
1/2 cup sugar
1/3 cup icing sugar, sifted
roasted strawberries and rhubarb:
1 quart strawberries (about 4 cups) - divided
1/2 lb rhubarb, trimmed and sliced 1” thick, about 2 cups
2 tbsp sugar
2 tbsp maple syrup
1 1/2 cups whipping cream
 
Method
Prepare the meringues a day ahead. Preheat oven to 175F and line a large baking sheet with parchment paper. In a mixer beat egg whites until white and frothy. Slowly add the 1/2 cup sugar and then keep beating a few minutes until stiff. Sift the icing sugar on top and fold it into the beaten whites. Spoon or pipe into 1 1/2” ‘blobs’ on prepared baking sheet. Bake 1 1/2 to 2 hours or longer until dry. Leave meringues in the turned off oven for another few hours or overnight.
For the roasted rhubarb and strawberries, preheat oven to 425F. Line a baking sheet with parchment paper. Clean and hull the berries and cut the small ones in half and the larger ones in thick slices. Reserve the nicest berries (about half) and place the other half on a baking sheet lined with parchment paper. Add sliced rhubarb to the baking pan of strawberries and combine. Sprinkle with sugar and drizzle with maple syrup. Bake about 20 minutes until rhubarb is tender. Cool and refrigerate. Place in a bowl and stir in the reserved uncooked strawberries.
Just before serving, whip cream until light and firm. Break meringue into uneven pieces. Fold into cream but not thoroughly. Fold in the fruit and thick juices but not thoroughly - it should be messy!
makes 6 to 8 servings #etonmess #eton #strawberries #rhubarb #cream #meringue #yum #motherdaughtercooking

Spareribs with Maple Chipotle BBQ Sauce
 
Even though many people barbecue all year now, there is something about barbecued ribs that say summer. Here's my favourite method - and use my current favourite quick sauce here or your own favourite sauce.
One secret to really tender ribs is to be sure the membrane on the underneath (bone) side has been removed. If not, cut away a small piece at the corner of a rib and holding the rack in place with a paper towel in one hand, with a paper towel in the other hand, grab the membrane and rip it off. You’ll feel very proud of yourself!
 
Ingredients
5 lbs/2.5kg back ribs (or side ribs)
2 tbsp all-purpose rub (or 1 tsp each kosher salt, sugar, cumin, paprika and 1/4 tsp black pepper)
barbecue sauce:
3/4 cup ketchup
1/2 cup chili sauce (ie. Heinz)
1/4 cup your favourite bbq sauce
3 tbsp maple syrup
2 tbsp Worcestershire sauce
2 tbsp apple cider vinegar
1 tbsp pureed chipotles (or chipotle hot sauce)
 
Method
1. Preheat oven to 300F. Line two sheet pans with aluminum foil hanging over the edges. Line with parchment paper.
Be sure the membrane is removed from the back of each rack of ribs. Rub both sides with rub. Place ribs in a single layer on the parchment. Cover with another sheet of parchment and then aluminum foil and scrunch the foil together until sealed. Place in the oven and cook 2 hours or longer until the ribs are very tender when pierced with a knife.
2. While ribs are cooking combine ketchup with chili sauce, bbq sauce, maple syrup, Worcestershire sauce, vinegar and chipotles.
3. When ribs are tender, remove the top foil and parchment paper. Drain off any liquid in the pan. Brush about 3/4 of the sauce on both sides of the ribs.
Increase oven temperature to 350F. Bake ribs 25 to 30 minutes or until browned.
4. When ready to serve, reheat the ribs on a medium hot barbecue for about 20 minutes, brushing with remaining sauce a few times.
Makes 6 servings #ribs #spareribs #bbq #bbqsauce #summercooking

Butter Tart Squares
 
I used to love my mom’s butter tarts with her all-butter pastry and lots of runny filling. Now I love butter tart squares the best because there is more filling in proportion to the pastry. They aren’t as runny, of course, but I can live with that. You can scatter raisins or chopped pecans over the pastry before pouring in the filling but we love them as is. These freeze well if there are any left.
 
Ingredients
crust:
1 cup all-purpose flour
2 tbsp sugar
1/4 tsp kosher salt
1/2 cup cold butter, cut into small cubes
filling:
1/4 cup butter
1 cup packed brown sugar
1/4 cup Lyle’s Syrup or corn syrup
2 eggs
1 tsp pure vanilla extract
4 tsp all-purpose flour
1/4 tsp baking powder
pinch kosher salt
icing sugar, optional
 
Method
Preheat oven to 350F. Butter an 8” square baking pan and line with parchment paper over hanging on two sides.
For the pastry place flour, sugar and salt in the bowl of a food processor fitted with the main blade. Blend together on/off a few times. Add butter and process on/off about 30 times until mixture almost forms a dough. Pat the mixture firmly into the bottom of prepared pan. Bake 25 to 30 minutes or longer until lightly browned. Reduce heat to 325F.
For filling, in the food processor or by hand, beat butter with sugar until mixed. Mix in syrup. Whisk in eggs one at a time and then beat in vanilla. Combine flour with baking powder and salt and mix in. 
Spread filling evenly over the crust. Bake 25 minutes or longer until browned and set - it should not jiggle but should not be too firm either. Check after 20 minutes and if the top is browning too much cover loosely with aluminum foil. 
Cool on a rack and refrigerate before removing from pan. Carefully remove the whole thing from pan in one piece to a cutting board. I usually trim the edges and eat them, and then cut the rest into 1 1/2” (ish) squares. (Dust with icing sugar if using.)
Makes about 16 to 20 squares #buttertarts #squares #canadaday #canadadaybaking #pastry

Onion and Potato Pakoras
After a recent tour of The Aga Kahn Museum in Toronto, we had lunch at their restaurant Diwan. Everything was delicious and the onion bhaji reminded me so much of the pakoras I used to make (in one of my first cookbooks, Appetizers) that I started making them again. Besan flour is chickpea flour and is naturally gluten free. The flavour is fantastic and it used to be hard to find but now it is easily available. Try to make these with onion and potatoes and then experiment with other vegetables.
These are usually deep-fried but I pan fry them. I hope you enjoy them as much as we do!
 
Ingredients
1 cup chick pea flour (sometimes called besan)
1 1/2 tsp kosher salt
1 tsp ground cumin
1 tsp sugar
3/4 tsp cayenne or Aleppo pepper (or harissa added after the water)
1/2 tsp each turmeric and ground coriander
1/2 tsp baking soda
3/4 cup ice water
1  8oz potato, coarsely grated or cut into small sticks
1 large-ish red onion, quartered and thinly sliced
1/4 cup chopped fresh cilantro
1 cup vegetable oil + more if necessary
sauce:
1 cup labaneh or thick yogurt
1 tbsp each chopped fresh mint and cilantro
1 tbsp lemon juice
 
Method
1. Combine besan flour with salt, cumin, cayenne, turmeric, coriander and baking soda. Stir in ice water until smooth (ish).
2. Stir in grated potato, onion and cilantro. (If mixture is too thick add a bit more water. )
3. Heat oil in a deep skillet. Drop large spoons of batter (about 2 tbsp) (I used a two tablespoon ice cream scoop and flattened the mixture slightly) and cook 2 to 3 minutes on each side until fully cooked. (Add additional oil between batches if necessary.) Drain on a rack set over a baking sheet or on paper towels. Serve hot or room temperature.
4. Combine ingredients for dip. Serve with pakoras.
Makes 20 to 24 #pakoras #chickpeaflour #besanflour #delicious #appetizers

Challah French Toast Casserole
This is the best way I know to use up leftover or stale challah whether home made or store-bought. This casserole is so delicious and is perfect for brunch (or any meal says Anna!) It is most delicious made with leftover challah (or babka) but you can certainly make it with other types of bread. I have been making this for years (it is in my Friday Night Dinners cookbook) and the recipe was given to me by my friend Helen Kirzner - may her memory be a blessing. It is delicious topped with berries or any seasonal fruit, compotes, or caramelized apples or bananas. Serve with yogurt or ice cream or serve savory style with bacon or sausages. Be sure to soak the bread overnight in the refrigerator (or at least a few hours) before baking.
 
Ingredients
7 eggs
2 1/2 cups milk
1 1/2 tsp pure vanilla extract 
1 to 1 1/4 lbs challah, crusts removed or not, cut into about 1” chunks (about 8 cups)
1/2 cup butter, melted
3/4 cup brown sugar
2 tbsp maple syrup
 
Method
1. In a large bowl whisk eggs with milk and vanilla. Add challah and push it under the egg mixture. Using the lid of a saucepan, or upside down dessert plate (or anything that fits inside the bowl) press the lid down on the bread that floats to the top and refrigerate overnight.
2. When ready to make, preheat oven to 350F. Butter or spray a 9”x13” baking dish or large casserole - I used an oven-safe pottery casserole (@ronityampottery) that is 10” across and 2” deep .  3. Transfer soaked challah to the prepared pan.
Whisk melted butter with sugar and maple syrup until mixture becomes smooth. Drizzle over the top.
4. Bake 45 to 50 minutes or longer until puffed and browned. Cool 5 minutes before serving. (Do not worry - it will deflate a little.)
Makes 6 to 8 servings #brunch #brunchrecipes #frenchtoast #frenchtoastcasserole #cottagecooking #dontworryjustcook #challah #leftovers

Fire and Ice Spaghetti Salad
 
When the temperature was hotter than ever recently, I remembered this all-time favourite spaghetti salad recipe and I started making it again! Serve this as a vegetarian/vegan main course or as a side dish at a barbecue.
Keep it simple as is, or you can add lots of delicious things - chunks of buffalo mozzarella or burrata, ripe avocado, roasted red or yellow peppers, olives, sun-dried tomatoes, capers, finely chopped anchovies, a mixture of fresh herbs, cooked shrimp or even a tin of olive oil packed tuna. I used ripe Compari tomatoes here - they were the ripest and reddest tomatoes I could find but ripe beefsteak would be great too. Now’s the time! 
 
Ingredients
1/3 cup extra virgin olive oil or more
2 cloves garlic, grated or minced
1/4 tsp hot red chili flakes - more or less to taste
1 tsp kosher salt or to taste
freshly ground black pepper
1/3 cup fresh basil leaves, torn into pieces or more to taste
1 lb ripe tomatoes, halved and diced
3/4 lb spaghetti
 
Method
1. Place oil in a large, shallow serving dish. Add garlic, chili flakes, salt, pepper and basil leaves. Add tomatoes and stir together gently. Marinate up to two hours at room temperature.
2. Cook spaghetti in a large pot of boiling, salted water until tender. Drain well (do not rinse) and toss with tomatoes. Season to taste. Serve right away or at room temperature.
Makes 4 to 5 servings #spaghetti #tomatoes #summercooking #summerrecipes #dontworryjustcook

Blueberry Crumble Muffins
 
It is (wild) blueberry season - my favourite season. I still remember having these delicious muffins about twenty years ago at Sooke Harbour House on Vancouver Island where owners Frederique and Sinclair Philip made it a world famous inn. The food was always great and the breakfast chef at that time, Frank Von Zuben, made the most amazing muffins. I have adapted his recipe a little since then but they are still so fantastic.(Sooke Harbour House has been closed for a few years and will be re-opening this winter.)
@canadianwildbb @thesirengroup thank you for the blueberries!!
Ingredients
crumble topping:
3/4 cup large flake oats
1/2 cup all-purpose flour
1/3 cup brown sugar
1 tsp baking powder
1/4 tsp cinnamon
1/4 tsp kosher salt
3 oz butter, cold, diced (1/3 cup + 1 tbsp)
muffins:
1/2 cup butter, diced
1/3 cup granulated sugar
1/3 cup brown sugar
2 eggs
1 tsp vanilla extract or paste
1/2 cup buttermilk (or yogurt thinned with a little milk)
2 cups all-purpose flour (or half whole wheat flour) + 1 tbsp to dust blueberries
1 tsp baking powder
1 tsp baking soda
1/4 tsp kosher salt
1 1/2 cup blueberries, fresh or frozen (I used wild blueberries)
Method
1. Preheat oven to 375F. Butter/spray a 12 cup muffin pan.
2. For the topping, in a food processor (or stand mixer with k-beater or by hand) combine the dry topping ingredients and then cut in the 3 oz of cold butter until it is in bits. Remove to a bowl.
3. For the muffins beat 1/2 cup butter with white and brown sugar until smooth. Beat in eggs, one at a time, the. buttermilk and vanilla. In a separate bowl whisk together 2 cups flour with baking powder, baking soda and salt. Mix dry ingredients into the butter/egg mixture. Dust the blueberries with remaining 1 tbsp flour and gently stir into the batter.
4. Divide batter between the 12 muffin cups. Top with as much topping as you can. Bake 25 to 30 minutes or until a toothpick inserted into the middle comes out clean or an instant read thermometer registers 185F to 195F. Makes 12 muffins #muffins #blueberries #blueberrymuffins #blueberrybaking #yum

* CONTEST CLOSED * (& recipe below) I’m so excited to be partnering with one of my favourite longtime brands @thepeppermate - I’ve used their peppermills for years and I’m giving away 5 of them! TO ENTER: follow @thepeppermate + like this post + comment and tag one friend you love to cook with! 

Rules: The contest closes on Aug 20 and winners will be chosen on Aug 21. Please beware of fake accounts contacting you. Only this verified Bonnie Stern account will DM you if you win. And this contest is only open to Canadian residents.  RECIPE: These delicious scrambled eggs are so easy to make. You just need freshly ground coarse black pepper, good cheese and patience to stir them. This is based on a popular brunch dish - cacio e pepe soft scrambled eggs from New York’s Maialino restaurant (a take-off of the famous pasta dish). Anna ate these eggs and knew we had to recreate them.
 
Ingredients
6 eggs
2 tbsp cream or milk
1/4 tsp kosher salt
1 tbsp butter
1/3 cup grated Parmigiano Reggiano or more to taste
1/4 tsp coarsely ground black pepper or more to taste 
pinch of flaky sea salt  1 tbsp chopped fresh parsley  Method
1. In a small mixing bowl whisk the eggs with cream and salt.
2. Melt butter in a 9 or 10" nonstick skillet over medium low heat. Add eggs and when they start to set at the edge of the pan (less than a minute) start stirring gently with a spatula. (Have patience - it will take 5 to 8 minutes to make the eggs creamy and scrambled without firm curds.)
3. A few minutes after soft curds start to form stir in the cheese. Have patience. Add pepper and still on medium low keep stirring until eggs have come together and are soft and very tender.
4. Transfer eggs to a plate and sprinkle with a little coarse sea salt, parsley and more pepper.
Makes 2 to 3 servings
#eggs #scrambledeggs #cacioepepe #pepper #peppermate #contest
