Adeena Sussman’s Cherry Tomato, Feta & Kalamata Salad
@acrupert and I recently met Jamie Milne of @everything_delish and we all bonded over our love of the wonderful @adeenasussman. So we decided to get together and cook a recipe from her new cookbook, Shabbat, and surprise her in the process. We love you Adeena!!! And we love your food and cookbooks. Check out Adeena’s profile for her book tour events and you can pre-order Shabbat now!! Here’s a delicious salad from the book. 
dressing:
1/4 cup freshly squeezed lemon juice
1/4 cup olive oil
1/4 tsp kosher salt (+ more for seasoning)
1/4 tsp freshly ground black pepper (+ more)
1/4 tsp ground coriander, optional
salad:
1 to 2 medium heirloom, beefsteak or vine-ripened tomatoes, sliced into rounds (3/4 lb)
3/4 lb multi-colored cherry tomatoes, halved
1/2 small red onion, sliced into half-moons
4 oz (1 cup) feta cheese, crumbled
1/2 cup lightly packed whole, fresh cilantro leaves
1/4 cup whole, pitted kalamata (or other) olives, halved
1 hot green chili pepper, seeded and cut into thin rounds, optional
 
Method
1. For dressing, in a jar with a lid, combine lemon juice, olive oil, salt, pepper and coriander (if using). Cover and shake until emulsified, 5 seconds. Dressing can be refrigerated, tightly sealed, in an airtight container for 1 week.
2. To assemble: In a salad bowl or on a platter, arrange the heirloom and cherry tomatoes, red onion, feta, cilantro, olives and chili (if using). Dress to your liking (Adeena says she generally uses it all), then season with salt and pepper and add more dressing as needed.
Serves 6 #salad #tomatoes #shabbatcookbook #adeenasussman #yum #newfriends #bestfriends

My gluten free daughter, Anna, alerted me to these delicious, naturally gf, old-fashioned cookies she discovered at a farmers’ market many years ago. There are lots of recipes for Monster Cookies online, with and without flour. I found the flour wasn’t necessary and decided to use a little oat flour. 
 
Ingredients
4 cups quick cooking oats (uncontaminated/gf oats if making gluten free)
1/2 cup oat flour
2 tsp baking soda
3/4 tsp kosher salt
1/2 cup butter
1 cup granulated sugar
1 cup brown sugar
3 eggs
1 1/2 cups peanut butter (smooth or crunchy), (not the natural kind)
2 tsp pure vanilla extract or paste
1 cup chocolate chips or chopped chocolate (milk or semisweet)
1/2 cup mini M&Ms (or any kind)
 
Method
1. Preheat oven to 350F. Line two 12" x 18" baking sheets with parchment paper.
2. In a large bowl mix together oats, oat flour, baking soda and salt. Reserve.
3. In another large bowl with a wooden spoon or hand mixer, or in the bowl of a stand mixer fitted with the paddle, cream butter with both types of sugar for a few minutes until light. Beat in eggs, one at a time. Beat in peanut butter until well combined and smooth. Add vanilla. Stir in oat mixture until well mixed and then stir in chocolate and mini M&Ms.
4. For large cookies (monster size) use a 2 oz ice cream scoop (1/4 cup) or for junior monster cookies use a 1 oz (2 tbsp) size for each cookie. Scoop onto lined baking sheets and gently press down a little, just to flatten the tops. (They do not spread too much.) 5. Bake 12 to 14 minutes for the large ones and 10 to 12 minutes for the smaller ones. Do not over bake. They should be crispy on the outside and chewy inside and about 1/2" thick. Cool pan on a rack about 10 minutes before removing cookies.
Makes approximately 32 large cookies or about 50 smaller ones. #oatmealcookies #peanutbuttercookies #monstercookies #yum

Grilled Corn and Cheese Quesadillas
 
This easy appetizer (or lunch or quick supper) has stood the test of time. Even just cheese, chipotle and cilantro taste amazing. Variations are as many as what you have leftover in your fridge. Other delicious additions are anything grilled or cooked like bacon, sausages, smoked turkey, rotisserie chicken, sauteed mushrooms and so much more.
Serve with salsa or guacamole or just eat them on their own. You can cook these on the barbecue, a grill pan, a panini maker or heavy skillet.
 
Ingredients
2 tbsp mayonnaise
1 tsp pureed chipotle chiles or other hot sauce of your choice
1 1/2 cups grated cheese (I like a combination of smoked Cheddar and mozzarella)
3/4 cup cooked corn kernels
3/4 cup leftover chopped cooked vegetables or grilled chicken
1/4 cup chopped fresh cilantro
8 to 10 flour tortillas (about 6” or 7” in diameter)(or corn tortillas)
 
Method
1. Combine mayonnaise with chipotle puree, cheese, corn and other cooked vegetables or meat.
2. Arrange tortillas on work surface in a single layer and place a spoonful of mixture on half of each tortilla. DO NOT OVERFILL. (That’s very hard to do.) Fold unfilled side over the filled side and press together.
3. Grill quesadillas a few minutes on a barbecue, grill pan, panini maker, sandwich press (or even a heavy skillet) or until cheese melts and tortillas are marked with grill marks. Cut into wedges.
Makes about 24 pieces
 
Note: If using corn tortillas, I use two rounds for each quesadillas and then cut them in quarters when they are ready. I have found they often break when folded - especially if they have been frozen. #quesadillas #cheese #yum #dontworryjustcook #summercooking #anytimecooking

Leftovers Fried Rice
 
Fried rice is one of my favourite ways to use up leftovers. And actually, you can make it with any leftover cooked grain or protein or vegetable. If you have raw vegetables, add them after the leeks or onions and cook about 5 minutes.
 
Ingredients
2 tbsp vegetable oil
1 small leek or onion, sliced or chopped
1 clove garlic, chopped
1/2" piece gingerroot, peeled and chopped
about 1 cup cooked steak, in 1" to 2" pieces
about 2 cups chopped cooked vegetables (in this case chopped raw carrots, and cooked broccolini)
2 cups cooked, cold rice, broken up
2 tbsp tamari or soy sauce
1 tsp dark sesame oil
1 egg, lightly beaten, optional
few tbsp chopped fresh cilantro
Method
1. Heat oil in a large non-stick pan. Add leeks, garlic and ginger and cook a few minutes until very fragrant.
2. Add steak and cooked vegetables and cook a minute or two until warm. Add rice, breaking it up and combining with meat and veg. Add tamari or soy sauce and sesame oil. Cook a few minutes until hot.
3. If using egg, clear away rice mixture from about a quarter of the pan. Add egg, scrambled lightly, break it up and combine with rice. Sprinkle with cilantro.
Make 2 to 4 servings #leftovers #friedrice #dontworryjustcook

Chocolate Date Nut Bark
 
By now you may have seen the frozen date bars on social media already but wondered, are they worth making? I would say a big YES! And so did everyone at Friday Night Dinner when I served them. (Special review by my good friend Elizabeth @duckandcake !) There are so many different versions and you can even make individual ones using each date on its own. I made mine with Bourbon Pecan Peanut Butter that I picked up on a recent trip to North Carolina but I have given lots of variations and options below.
Perfect for an ‘anytime at all’ treat. I now keep them in the freezer.
 
Ingredients
12 Medjool dates
1/4 cup pecan or regular peanut butter, almond butter, tahini, Lotus Biscoff Spread, cashew butter etc
6oz semisweet, bittersweet, white or milk chocolate, chopped (if not already in smallish pieces), melted
1/4 cup chopped toasted pecans or peanuts or almonds (or more) or pumpkin or sunflower seeds 
flaky sea salt (ie Maldon), optional
 
Method
Slit each date from top to bottom and remove pit (and stem end if it is still there). Open dates and place together in a single layer on a 9 »x13 » piece of parchment paper that lines a quarter sheet pan. Cover with another piece of parchment or plastic wrap and flatten with a rolling pin (or Bordeaux wine bottle).
Spread dates with nut butter or alternative. Use a bit more if necessary. If you wish, sprinkle with some of the chopped nuts. Refrigerate 1/2 hour.
Drizzle and then spread with melted chocolate. Sprinkle with remaining nuts and flaky salt if using. Refrigerate or freeze until chocolate sets. 
Cut into chunky, different sized pieces.
Makes 20 to 24 irregular sized pieces #dates #datebark #yum

Smoky Sweet Potato Bruschetta with Black Beans, Gaucamole and Corn 

These are as delicious as they are beautiful, can be an appetizer, side or a vegan main and were inspired by a dish I had at Luna Rotisserie in Durham NC that describes their food as South American meets the American South. You can use the sweet potatoes themselves as a side dish, the black bean mixture as a dip or spread, the guacamole (you know what to do) and you can grill lots of corn and freeze it for later.

Ingredients
2 lbs (fat) sweet potatoes, peeled and sliced 1 » thick and about 3 » across (you should have about 10 pieces) but roast any extra pieces and eat them  3 tbsp extra virgin olive oil
1 tbsp maple syrup
1 tbsp pureed chipotle chiles or tabasco
1 tsp kosher salt
1/4 tsp smoked paprika
black bean spread:
1 cup cooked (canned) black beans
1 tbsp lime juice (or more to taste)
1 clove garlic, minced
1/4 tsp ground cumin
1 tbsp chopped fresh cilantro
guacamole:
1 cup fresh cilantro leaves and small stems
1/2 jalapeno chile (seeds and veins removed)
1/2 tsp kosher salt or more to taste
2 to 3 tbsp lime juice or more to taste
2 ripe avocadoes
3 ears corn, grilled or broiled

Method
Method
For sweet potatoes, preheat oven to 425F. Line baking sheet with parchment paper. Combine olive oil in large bowl with maple syrup, chipotles, salt and paprika. Toss with sweet potatoes. Arrange on baking sheet and roast, turning once, 30 to 40 minutes until browned and tender. Cool.
For black bean spread, mash or coarsely puree beans with lime juice, garlic, cumin and cilantro. Adjust seasoning with salt and lime juice.
For guac, chop cilantro with as much chile as you like, and salt. Coarsely mash avocado pieces into the cilantro mixture. Season to taste with lime juice and salt. Cover surface directly with plastic wrap to prevent discolouration.
Grill corn on medium heat until corn is cooked and browned in spots, or boil 5 minutes. Cool. Slice corn off the cobb from top to bottom.
To assemble, arrange the sweet potatoes on a platter, spread with black bean mixture, top with guacamole and sprinkle with corn and extra cilantro leaves.
makes 10 pieces
#sweetpotatoes #thanksgivingrecipes

It’s Friday and we’re making challah! How about you? Anna asked me if I could share a few tips with you and here they are: don’t over knead the dough (don’t let your arms get too tired), don’t let the dough over rise (it should just double), don’t add too much flour (you want it to be slightly tacky but not sticky) and don’t over bake it (a thermometer should read 195F. And we also shared a braiding technique I learned from @urischeft of @lehamimbakery #shabbatshalom #challah #challahtips #dontworryjustcook

Hi everyone, Anna and I haven’t posted a recipe since before October 7th. It hasn’t been a priority for us in light of all that happened and is still going on. We also know from when we posted recipes during COVID and from what some of us are feeling now, that cooking and taking care of others and showing love is a way to take care of ourselves and show kindness. So we wanted to share a recipe we made this week for a leek and potato soup. We hope if you feel up to making it, it brings you comfort. Sending everyone love and hope, Bonnie and Anna. #shabbatshalom  This classic, delicious soup has stood the test of time. Comfort food to be sure.  Ingredients
2 tbsp extra virgin olive oil or butter
3 leeks (about 1 1/2 lbs), white and light green parts, well cleaned and chopped
3 large baking potatoes (about 2 1/2 lbs), peeled and cut into chunks
4 cups chicken or vegetable broth or water, more if necessary
kosher salt and freshly ground pepper to taste
sprig of fresh thyme or 1/2 tsp dried
1/2 cup whole milk or whipping cream, optional
chopped fresh chives or parsley
 
Method
1. Heat oil or butter on medium low in a large saucepan or medium Dutch oven. Add cleaned leeks and cook gently about 10 to 15 minutes or until softened. Do not brown.
2. Add potatoes and stir into leeks. Add stock and bring to a boil. Add salt and pepper (amount depends on the saltiness of the stock) and thyme. Add more liquid if necessary - it should cover the vegetables. Reduce heat to medium low and cook gently about 25 to 30 minutes or longer if necessary so that potatoes are very tender.
3. I like the soup chunky-ish so I mash it with a potato masher. Stir in milk or cream (I usually use cream) or additional stock or water to get the texture you like and heat thoroughly. If you want the soup more pureed - use an immersion blender (or blender) but do not puree very long as it makes potatoes gummy.
4. Taste and adjust seasoning (discard the sprig of the fresh thyme if you used that). Sprinkle with chives or parsley.
Makes 4 to 6 servings #leekandpotatosoup #comfortfood #soupseason #shabbatshalom

Pear and Apple Crisp - Sometimes the best recipes happen by accident. One time I was supposed to be making Ray’s favourite dessert, apple crisp, but I had run out of apples. I had some pears so I used them and had one apple that I also added. Everyone (including Ray) said it was the best apple crisp I had ever made.
Ingredients
1 1/2 lbs pears,  peeled, halved, core removed and cut into chunks
3/4 lb apples, peeled, halved, core removed and cut into chunks
1 cup all-purpose flour, whole wheat or gluten-free
1/3 cup brown sugar
1/3 cup granulated sugar
3/4 tsp ground cinnamon 
Pinch kosher salt
1/2 cup cold butter, cut into pieces or grated
Vanilla Ice cream or whipped cream or yogurt (unnecessary but wouldn’t hurt)
 Method
1. Preheat oven to 350F. Butter a 9” square baking dish. 
2. Place pears and apples (about 6 to 7 cups) in the buttered baking dish. 
3. In a large bowl mix together flour, brown sugar, granulated sugar, cinnamon and salt. Cut in butter with a pastry blender or your finger tips until it is in small bits and flour mixture is sticky. (This can be done in a food processor, stand mixer with the k-beater, or by hand with a pastry blender or your fingers). Sprinkle evenly over the pears and apples.
4. Bake 45 to 50 minutes until topping is lightly browned and crisp. 
Serve warm or cold, as is or with vanilla ice cream or whipped cream or yogurt. 
Makes 6 to 8 servings #comfortfood #applecrisp

I always say my favourite part of travelling is getting home, which is usually true, but I have to say @fairmontjpl made Anna and I feel so at home the last almost two weeks. We were presenters this year at their annual Christmas in November festival - Anna for the first time and me for the first time in 30 years! We didn’t know what to expect, and while it was hard work, it was also amazing. The hospitality of all the staff, the beauty of the lodge and the surroundings, the knowledge, expertise and hilariousness of the presenters and the happiness and joy of all the participants made it truly an incredible experience. Homemade Gingerale and Ginger Tea
When we were part of Christmas in November at Jasper Park Lodge this year, we learned there was homemade gingerale at the bar (and ginger tea) and the bartender Matthew was kind enough to share how it was made. He also told us we have the @thewillowstrio to thank for its creation because they asked for something gingery to soothe their throats for singing! We tried the gingerale and we are not looking back. Gingerale and always makes us feel better if we are feeling sick but even when we feel fine, we feel better after drinking it. Especially now with this homemade version! Be sure to follow us for more recipes and mother daughter fun ❤️
 
Ingredients
ginger puree:
6 oz candied ginger (or crystallized ginger)
3/4 cup hot water (or a little more if necessary)
honey syrup:
1/2 cup honey
1/2 cup boiling water
lemon juice
1/2 cup fresh lemon juice (2 or 3 lemons)
 
Method
1. Place the candied ginger in a blender and cover with hot (not boiling) water. Cover container and puree until very smooth. Transfer to a jar,  cover, label  and store in the refrigerator for a week or 2 or freeze. 
2. For the honey syrup combine honey with boiling water, bring to a boil, and cook 2 minutes. Transfer to a jar, cool, cover, label and store in the refrigerator.
3. Soften the lemons with your hands, cut in half, juice - you should have about 1/2 cup. Transfer to a jar, cover, label and refrigerate.
4. For gingerale, place 1 1/2 tbsp ginger mixture, 1 tbsp honey syrup and 1 tbsp lemon juice in a tall glass, stir, add ice and fill with soda water. Stir well. Garnish with a wedge of lemon and piece of candied ginger. For ginger tea, place 1 1/2 tbsp ginger mixture in a mug, add 1 tbsp honey syrup and 1 tbsp lemon juice and fill the cup with boiling water. Candied ginger purée will keep in the fridge for 1-2 weeks and otherwise freeze in ice cube trays.
Yum either way. #jasperparklodge #jaspercin #gingerale #gingertea

Bonnie’s Challah
Challah is not about perfection, it’s about tradition and family, so even if making bread intimidates you, try making my challah. Makes 2 large or 3 medium loaves
Ingredients:
6 to 7 cups (or more) all-purpose flour 
1 tbsp kosher salt
1/2 cup sugar
1 1/2 tbsp instant dry yeast
2 eggs
1 1/2 cups warm (not hot) water
1/2 cup vegetable oil or extra virgin olive oil or half/half
Glaze:
1 egg lightly beaten
1 tsp water
1/4 tsp kosher salt
sesame or poppy seeds or flaky salt 
Method
1. Place 5 1/2 cups flour in a large bowl or work bowl of stand mixer. Whisk in salt, sugar and yeast.
2. In another bowl whisk eggs with water and oil.
3. Stir liquid ingredients into dry ingredients with a wooden spoon if by hand, or with dough hook in a stand mixer on low. Dough will be sticky. Stir in more flour about 1/4 cup at a time until less sticky. If by hand, stir in just enough flour until dough is too stiff to keep stirring. Sprinkle 1/4 cup flour on work surface. Turn dough out onto flour. Knead in enough flour (adding more if needed) so dough doesn’t stick to your hands but is moist - about 10 mins. I usually use 6 to 6 1/2 cups total. In stand mixer add enough flour so dough does not stick to sides of the bowl (okay if sticks to bottom). Knead in the mixer about 4 mins until soft and silky. finish kneading by hand. (It’s better to have a slightly soft, moist dough.) 
4. Place 1 tbsp veg oil in a large bowl. Place dough in bowl and turn it to oil all over. Cover. Let rise until almost doubled (1 1/2 to 2 hours). Gently push (not punch) dough to release air, knead again to form a ball. Braid as you wish. Place on parchment paper-lined baking sheets or in baking pans. Cover loosely with oiled wrap and let rise 30 to 60 minutes or almost doubled. Small challahs will rise faster.
5. Mix egg with water and salt. Brush challah with mixture. Sprinkle with seeds or salt or leave plain.Bake in a preheated 350F oven 25 to 30 minutes - small breads will bake faster, big breads will take longer. Bake until an instant read thermometer inserted into the middle of the bread reaches 185F to 195F. Remove bread from pan and cool on a wire rack. #challah #jewishandcanadian

Linda Rose’s Pecan Squares
 
When there are so many recipes for pecan squares, how does one choose? Choose this one from Chef Anthony Rose’s amazing mom Linda. These are the best I have ever tried. Anthony is one of my favourite chefs and we always joke that I have known him his whole life - even before he was born. You see his mother Linda took cooking classes from me when she was pregnant with him! Linda adapted this recipe slightly from @onceuponachef and I adapted it slightly from Linda - that’s how recipes travel. Serve at room temperature. And know they freeze well.
Ingredients
shortbread base:
3/4 cup all-purpose flour
1/4 cup cornstarch
1/2 cup icing sugar, sifted
1/2 tsp kosher salt
1/2 cup cold  butter, cut into about 1/2” pieces
filling:
3/4 cup butter
3/4 cup light brown sugar
3 tbsp maple syrup or honey
1 tsp pure vanilla paste or extract
1/4 tsp kosher salt
2 tbsp whipping cream
2 1/2 cups coarsely chopped pecans (preferably roasted)
Method
1. Preheat oven to 350F. Butter or spray a 9” square baking pan and line with parchment paper so the paper hangs over two opposite sides (for easy removal later).
2. For the base, place flour, cornstarch, icing sugar and salt in the bowl of a food processor fitted with the main blade. Pulse a few times to blend. Add the cold butter and pulse until mixture just starts to come together and resembles coarse breadcrumbs. You can also do this with a hand mixer or by hand. Press into the bottom of the prepared pan. Bake in the preheated oven 15 to 17 minutes or until pastry is set but not brown. Cool on a rack until filling is ready.
3. For the filling, place the butter, brown sugar, maple syrup and salt in a medium saucepan on medium heat. Stir until sugar dissolves and then bring to a boil and boil gently 3 minutes. Stir in vanilla, cream and then pecans. Pour over the crust (don’t worry if crust is still warm). Bake until bubbly and caramel coloured - about 20 minutes. Cool completely on a rack.
4. To cut, gently lift the ‘cake’ out of the pan to a cutting board and cut into squares or bars.
Makes 16 large or 25 medium squares or cut into larger pieces for dessert with ice cream. #yum #pecansquares #dessert

Creamy Rice Pudding with Caramelized Bananas 
Rice pudding is comfort food at its’ best. The pudding is delicious warm or cold. It firms us when cold so while the pudding is warm spoon it into small serving dishes or a large bowl to portion at serving time.
Ingredients
rice pudding:
2/3 cup Italian short grain rice
1 1/3 cups boiling water
5 cups whole milk or 2% milk
1/3 cup sugar
1/2 tsp kosher salt
1 vanilla bean, cut in half and slit open, optional
1/2 cup whipping cream (or additional milk)
2 egg yolks, optional
1 tbsp pure vanilla extract (if not using vanilla bean)
caramelized bananas:
1/2 cup sugar
1/2 cup whipping cream (must be whipping cream)
1/4 tsp kosher salt
4 bananas, sliced 1/2” thick just before serving
Method
1. Place rice and boiling water in large saucepan and bring to a boil, reduce heat to medium low, cover pot and cook gently 15 minutes or until rice absorbs water.
2. Add 5 cups milk to rice, bring almost to boil on medium-high heat. Watch closely as milk likes to burn/ boil over. Stir in sugar, salt and vanilla bean. Partially cover and cook gently, 30 minutes, stirring often. (If your pudding boils over you will take to heart my advice to use a large pot, keep heat low and stir. You are looking for the rice to be tender/thicken the milk to a loose pudding consistency. You want milk and rice to be married, not separated. 
3. Add cream to rice mixture and stir well. Increase heat slightly and cook, stirring, until thick, 5 to 10 minutes. 
4. Whisk egg yolks, if using, in medium bowl and stir 1 cup rice mixture into the yolks a little at a time to warm. Return everything to the pot and cook gently 2 to 3 minutes. Remove from heat. Remove vanilla been or stir in vanilla extract now.
5. For caramel, put sugar in a 10” heavy, non-stick skillet on medium heat. Without stirring let melt, 2 to 3 minutes, until sugar begins to turn caramel colour (be careful it doesn’t burn). Stand back, add cream. Stir well. Add salt. Just before serving add bananas. #ricepudding #caramel #caramelizedbananas #comfortfood

Chocolate Soufflé Roulade with Coffee Caramel Cream
 
This elegant rolled souffle cake is just as delicious now as when I started making it many many years ago. Lots of people worry about rolling it up but don’t! If it cracks a bit it will still look and taste great and remember - it can always be turned into a trifle served from a pretty bowl. You can serve with chocolate or caramel sauce but also delicious as is.
Ingredients
cake:
6 eggs, separated
3/4 cup sugar, divided
1/3 cup unsweetened cocoa, sifted
pinch kosher salt
1 tsp vanilla extract
2 tbsp icing sugar or cocoa, sifted
filling:
3/4 cup whipping cream, very cold
2 tbsp icing sugar, sifted
1 tsp instant espresso powder or finely ground instant coffee
about 1/2 cup chopped chocolate coated caramel bars
 
Method
1. Butter or spray a 9”x13” sheet pan and line with parchment paper. Preheat oven to 350F.
2. In a large bowl with a whisk or electric mixer beat egg yolks with 1/2 cup of the sugar until light and thick. Beat in cocoa and vanilla.
3. In a clean bowl with clean beaters whip egg whites until they turn white and slowly add remaining 1/4 cup sugar. Continue beating until stiff peaks form. Stir about 1/4 of the whites into the cocoa mixture to lighten it and then fold in the remaining egg whites.
4. Spread souffle mixture evenly over the prepared pan and bake 14 to 16 minutes until puffed and top feels firm and dry. Cool in pan on a rack (souffle will fall) at least 15 minutes. Dust top of cake with cocoa or icing sugar and loosen from the edges of the pan. Invert onto another piece of parchment paper. Cool completely.
5. Whip cream in a large bowl and when it starts to thicken beat in icing sugar and espresso powder. Spread cream evenly over the cooled cake and sprinkle with chopped caramel bars.
6. Roll up cake (lengthwise for a long thin cake or widthwise for a pudgier cake) using the parchment paper to help you roll and then gently roll onto a serving plate. Rerigerate until ready to serve. 
Makes 8 servings #roulade #chocolate #dontworryjustcook #holidaybaking #holidaydesserts

Anna’s House Salad Dressing
 
This is the salad dressing that changed Anna’s salad life. Anna never liked salad but one day came home from university and told me she had big news - she ate a salad and kind of liked it. Together we recreated it, making this dressing here. She has never looked back. (Mothers of fussy eaters - say nothing. I know it’s hard but one day they will have an epiphany.)
This dressing is very versatile - in the video I put together something extremely simple but you can add tomatoes, cucumber, raw or cooked vegetables, grilled chicken, chopped fresh cilantro and more to any lettuce you like. PS - you may have noticed the dressing in our photo is labelled Sept 30 2023 and it’s no longer Sept 2023 (although I’m sure we wish it was). So forgive us, we made this video for you then, and hadn’t been able to share it until now. We hope you love it. 
Ingredients
3 tbsp seasoned rice vinegar (or lemon juice, apple cider vinegar or regular rice vinegar + a little more honey and salt)
1 clove garlic, grated or very finely chopped
1/2 tsp kosher salt
1 tbsp soy sauce (or tamari)
1 tbsp honey
1/4 tsp toasted sesame oil
1/3 cup vegetable oil or extra virgin olive oil
gem or Romain lettuce
Method
1. Place all ingredients (except lettuce) in a 2 cup/500mL preserving jar, close tightly with lid and shake like crazy. Taste on a lettuce leaf.
2. Drizzle lettuce with a few tablespoons of dressing and toss well.
3. Label remaining dressing with name and date. Keeps in the refrigerator about 5 days.
makes about 2/3 cup #salad #saladdressing #dontworryjustcook #fussyeaters #pickyeaters
